content.question:
Refer to figure.
An aircraft is executing a VFR navigation. The navigation log refers to a leg that begins over CWD VOR/DME. The aircraft reaches CWD VOR/DME at 10:06 UTC and then follows the calculated heading and speed. At 10:21 UTC the aircraft is on radial 247° at a DME distance of 24 NM from CWD VOR/DME. The cross-track error is.

key_points: The aircraft is on radial 247° magnetic
In order to find cross track error, we need to compare the planned Magnetic Track with the actual Magnetic Track

Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least True track (T) Variation (V) Magnetic track (M) Deviation (D) Compass track (C) 241° 2°W 243° - - Calculate Track Error (TKE) TKE = Actual Track – Planned Track = 247° - 243° = 4° Calculate cross-track error The 1:60 rule states that: "For each degree of drift angle you will be one NM off-track having travelled 60 NM along track"
learning.explanation: The aircraft is on radial 247° magnetic. In order to find cross track error, we need to compare the planned Magnetic Track with the actual Magnetic Track. Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least True track (T) Variation (V) Magnetic track (M) Deviation (D) Compass track (C) 241° 2°W 243° - - Calculate Track Error (TKE) TKE = Actual Track – Planned Track = 247° - 243° = 4° Calculate cross-track error The 1:60 rule states that: "For each degree of drift angle you will be one NM off-track having travelled 60 NM along track". If you are only 20 NM along track, every one degree of drift angle relates to one third of a NM. If so, 2 NM off-track must equate to a 6° drift angle and 3 NM off-track must equate to a 9° drift angle. Applying the 1:60 rule, an aircraft which has a drift angle of 4° after 60 NM, will be 4 NM off-track. Thus, after 24 NM, the aircraft will have a cross-track error of: 4° x 24 / 60 NM = 1.6 NM

key_points: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T
In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole
The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located
learning.explanation: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T. In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole. The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located. Magnetic Direction, have as reference the Magnetic North Pole and is assigned an angular value of 000º M or 360º M. Variation is the angle between the True and Magnetic North and is assigned in degrees East or West of the True North. If the Magnetic North is west of the True North, westerly variation, the magnetic direction will have a higher angular value than the true direction. If the Magnetic North is east of the True North, easterly variation, the magnetic direction will have a lower angular value than the true direction. Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least The utility of a magnetic compass on the aircraft will depend on the accuracy of its response to the magnetic field of the earth. The metallic structure of the airplane, its engine and equipment can affect the accuracy of the compass, an effect called the compass deviation. Compass deviation is defined by the number of degrees by which unwanted magnetic fields deflect the compass from magnetic north indication (desired indication). Deviation (-) West – Compass Best Deviation (+) East – Compass Least Drift or drift angle, is the angular difference between the track of the aircraft across and it's heading. Always remember that the drift angle is always measured with reference to the heading. The heading is the direction in witch the the aircraft’s nose is pointing for. True Track is 352º with drift 10º R, means that TT is right of Heading 342º (T). True heading (T) Variation (V) Magnetic heading (M) Deviation (D) Compass heading (C) 342º 11ºW 353º 5ºW 358º

content.question: The Equator is a…

options.A: great circle with its plane perpendicular to the Earth’s rotational axis.
options.B: small circle with its plane perpendicular to the Earth’s rotational axis.
options.C: great circle with its plane parallel to the Earth’s rotational axis.
options.D: small circle with its plane parallel to the Earth’s rotational axis.

key_points: EQUATOR The Equator is the intersection of the Earth's surface with the plane perpendicular to the Earth's axis of rotation
It is an imaginary line on the Earth's surface equidistant from the North Pole and South Pole that divides the Earth into a Northern Hemisphere and Southern Hemisphere
A Great Circle is any circle that circumnavigates the Earth and passes through the center of the Earth
learning.explanation: EQUATOR The Equator is the intersection of the Earth's surface with the plane perpendicular to the Earth's axis of rotation. It is an imaginary line on the Earth's surface equidistant from the North Pole and South Pole that divides the Earth into a Northern Hemisphere and Southern Hemisphere. A Great Circle is any circle that circumnavigates the Earth and passes through the center of the Earth. A Great Circle always divides the Earth in half, thus the Equator is a Great Circle (the only line of latitude which is also a Great Circle).

The Charter flight log is filled out correctly by the pilot of a light twin-engined aeroplane. Calculate the average Groundspeed from TOC to TORDU and the ETA at RODRA.

key_points: The aircraft covered the flight leg fromTOC to TORDU in: 06:46 - 06:10 = 36 min
So, its Average Actual Groundspeed will be: TOC - TORDU distance / TOC - TORDU time = (73 + 37 NM / 36 min) x 60 = 183 kt
From TOC to RODRA, the altitude (FL090), TAS (190 kt), Track (047) and Heading (055) remain the same
learning.explanation: The aircraft covered the flight leg fromTOC to TORDU in: 06:46 - 06:10 = 36 min. So, its Average Actual Groundspeed will be: TOC - TORDU distance / TOC - TORDU time = (73 + 37 NM / 36 min) x 60 = 183 kt. From TOC to RODRA, the altitude (FL090), TAS (190 kt), Track (047) and Heading (055) remain the same. The 1º increase in both track and heading at the last flight leg is negligible and will not alter the result significantly. Thus, the flight time from TORDU to RODRA is: TORDU - RODRA distance / Actual GS = (71 NM / 183 kt) x 60 = 23 min. Therefore, the ETA at RODRA will be: ATO TORDU + flight time from TORDU to RODRA = 06:46 + 23 = 07:09.

content.question: The length of one minute of arc along a meridian is equal to one NM (1 852 m) at approximately latitude:

key_points: Because the Earth is flattened at the Poles, the radius of curvature is increased and a greater arc is required to subtend an angle of one minute at the centre of curvature, hence a nautical mile is longer at the Poles, at about 1 862 m

The amount of curvature is greatest at the Equator (the radius of curvature is decreased) and therefore the length of arc required to generate an angle of one minute at the centre of curvature is less
A nautical mile is shortest at the Equator and measures about 1 844 m
learning.explanation: Because the Earth is flattened at the Poles, the radius of curvature is increased and a greater arc is required to subtend an angle of one minute at the centre of curvature, hence a nautical mile is longer at the Poles, at about 1 862 m. The amount of curvature is greatest at the Equator (the radius of curvature is decreased) and therefore the length of arc required to generate an angle of one minute at the centre of curvature is less. A nautical mile is shortest at the Equator and measures about 1 844 m. The average value is 1 852 m, which would correspond to 1 minute of arc of a Meridian measured at a latitude of approximately 45°. content.question: Where is it more likely to find high values of variation?

key_points: Magnetic variation is the angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian

It varies across the Earth between 180º, on a line joining the true and magnetic poles (the magnetic compass is pointing at the Magnetic North Pole, whilst the tail of the needle is pointing at the Geographic North Pole) and 0º, where this line is extended beyond the poles
Lines joining points of equal variation on the Earth's surface are called "isogonals" and the line along which variation is zero is called "agonic line"
learning.explanation: Magnetic variation is the angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian. It varies across the Earth between 180º, on a line joining the true and magnetic poles (the magnetic compass is pointing at the Magnetic North Pole, whilst the tail of the needle is pointing at the Geographic North Pole) and 0º, where this line is extended beyond the poles. Lines joining points of equal variation on the Earth's surface are called "isogonals" and the line along which variation is zero is called "agonic line". The isogonals converge at the magnetic poles and at the true poles. The Earth's magnetic pole is slowly moving around the true pole at high latitudes, so variation changes over time.

Magnetic track 010º, magnetic heading 020º, TAS 260kt and variation 20ºW. Aircraft travels 57 NM in 15 minutes. Calculate the W/V (ºT)?

key_points: Drift or drift angle, is the angular difference between the track of the aircraft and its heading
Keep in mind, to determine the drift the reference is heading to track
In this case, Heading is 020º and the Track is 010º, therefore we have 10º left drift
learning.explanation: Drift or drift angle, is the angular difference between the track of the aircraft and its heading. Keep in mind, to determine the drift the reference is heading to track. In this case, Heading is 020º and the Track is 010º, therefore we have 10º left drift. Ground Speed = (57 NM / 15 min) x 60 min = 228 kt Determining winds with the flight computer: 1. Set True Heading (020ºM) under "True Index" 2. Place centre dot over TAS (260 kts) 3. Mark the point where drift (10ºL) and GS (228 kt) meet. 4. Rotate the wind computer until mark is below TAS. 5. Check wind direction under "True Index" (68º M) 6. Count down from TAS to obtain wind speed (260 - 206 = 54 kt) W/V = 068º M / 54 kt => The question asks for W/V in (ºT), therefore we must apply the variation: Magnetic versus True Use this mnemonic to remember that with variation west, the magnetic direction is going to be "best" or greater than true. Variation is added to true to arrive at magnetic, or subtracted from magnetic to get true. 068ºM - 20ºW = 048ºT W/V = 048ºT / 54 kt

content.question: Aircraft departs from A, to point B which is 45 NM away. After 7 min or 12 NM, the aircraft is 3 NM left off track. What is the change of heading required to fly direct to point B.

key_points: Calculate the TKE (Track Angle Error) to give us the heading correction in order to parallel our intended track: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track TKE = (3 × 60) ÷ 12 TKE = 15° If we alter our heading by 15° (towards the original track) we will parallel our original track
In order to re-join the original track, we must calculate the track correction for the distance to go: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance to go TKE = (3 × 60) ÷ 33 TKE = 5º (approx
) So turning 15° will parallel our track, and turning an extra 5° on top of that will direct us to the final destination
learning.explanation: Calculate the TKE (Track Angle Error) to give us the heading correction in order to parallel our intended track: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track TKE = (3 × 60) ÷ 12 TKE = 15° If we alter our heading by 15° (towards the original track) we will parallel our original track. In order to re-join the original track, we must calculate the track correction for the distance to go: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance to go TKE = (3 × 60) ÷ 33 TKE = 5º (approx.) So turning 15° will parallel our track, and turning an extra 5° on top of that will direct us to the final destination. Therefore, 15° + 5° = 20º would be the total alteration required (to re-join the original track). The deviation was to the left, therefore we must fly 20º to the right. content.question: You are planning to fly from waypoint A (46°35'00''N, 175°26'39''E) to waypoint B (28°24'00''S, 175°26'39''E). What is the distance between these two waypoints?

key_points: The two points A and B have the same longitude (175°26'39''E), so what we are dealing with here is, a Change of Latitude along the same meridian, between 46°35'00''N and 28°24'00''S
For Change of Latitude and Change of Longitude calculations, bear in mind the rule: "Same hemispheres - Subtract, Different hemispheres - Add"
The two latitudes are in different hemispheres, so add to find the Change of Latitude: 46o35'00'' + 28°24'00'' = 74o59'00''
learning.explanation: The two points A and B have the same longitude (175°26'39''E), so what we are dealing with here is, a Change of Latitude along the same meridian, between 46°35'00''N and 28°24'00''S. For Change of Latitude and Change of Longitude calculations, bear in mind the rule: "Same hemispheres - Subtract, Different hemispheres - Add". The two latitudes are in different hemispheres, so add to find the Change of Latitude: 46o35'00'' + 28°24'00'' = 74o59'00''. 1 degree is 60 minutes, so the Change of Latitude can be re-written in minutes as: (74o x 60') + 59' = 4499'. Also, it is known that 1' along a meridian equals to 1 NM. Therefore, the distance between A and B points is 4499 NM.

The difference between TAS and GS is the wind
So one would assume that, in zero wind conditions, NAM = NGM
learning.explanation: NAM = NGM x TAS/GS NGM = NAM x GS/TAS Where, NAM stands for Nautical Air miles, NGM is Nautical Ground miles, TAS is True airspeed and GS stands for ground speed. The difference between TAS and GS is the wind. So one would assume that, in zero wind conditions, NAM = NGM. However, practically speaking, due to the difference of radius at different heights (greater radius at greater height), the air distance will be slightly greater than the ground distance.

content.question:
Given:
Distance A to B = 150 NM.After 30 NM aircraft is 4 NM to the right of course.What heading alteration should be made in order to arrive at point "B"?

key_points: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning
If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track
The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good
learning.explanation: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning. If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track. The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good. The difference between them is called track error (TE). The angle at which we want to close to come back to the planned track is the closing angle (CA). The CA will depend how much further we want to rejoin the planned track. The 1 in 60 rule can be used to calculate the TE and the CA. TE = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 TE = (4/30) x 60 = 8º The same 1 in 60 rule can be applied to calculate the CA. CA = (distance off-track/distance at which we want to rejoin track) x 60 CA = (4 / (150 - 30)) x 60 = 2º With both TE and CA, we can determine by how much heading change we should apply to regain track: Heading change = TE + CA = 8º + 2º = 10º L The aircraft is right off-track, the aircraft must fly left to regain track.

content.question: The angle between Magnetic North and Compass North is called..

key_points: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T
In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole
The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located
learning.explanation: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T. In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole. The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located. Magnetic Direction, have as reference the Magnetic North Pole and is assigned an angular value of 000º M or 360º M. Variation is the angle between the True and Magnetic North and is assigned in degrees East or West of the True North. If the Magnetic North is west of the True North, westerly variation, the magnetic direction will have a higher angular value than the true direction. If the Magnetic North is east of the True North, easterly variation, the magnetic direction will have a lower angular value than the true direction. Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least The utility of a magnetic compass on the aircraft will depend on the accuracy of its response to the magnetic field of the earth. The metallic structure of the airplane, its engine and equipment can affect the accuracy of the compass, an effect called the compass deviation. Compass deviation is defined by the number of degrees by which unwanted magnetic fields deflect the compass from magnetic north indication (desired indication). Deviation (-) West – Compass Best Deviation (+) East – Compass Least

When transforming True Heading (TH) into Magnetic Heading (MH) and vice versa, we consider magnetic variation. Remember the mnemonic "West is Best, East is Least". Westerly variation increases TH (+), whereas easterly variation reduces it (-). content.question: The charted values of magnetic variation on Earth normally change annually due to...

options.B: magnetic pole movement causing numerical values at all locations to increase or decrease.

options.D: magnetic pole movement causing numerical values at all locations to increase.

key_points: The magnetic variation is caused by the different locations of the geographic (true) North Pole and the magnetic North Pole
The horizontal component of the Earth’s magnetic field is the part that is detected by the compass needle in order to determine Magnetic North
Therefore, it is accurate enough to say that variation is the angle between the horizontal component of the magnetic field and the true north direction
learning.explanation: The magnetic variation is caused by the different locations of the geographic (true) North Pole and the magnetic North Pole. The horizontal component of the Earth’s magnetic field is the part that is detected by the compass needle in order to determine Magnetic North. Therefore, it is accurate enough to say that variation is the angle between the horizontal component of the magnetic field and the true north direction. At a specific location, the value of magnetic variation varies slowly over time. In fact, the magnetic pole is constantly moving, causing the values at all locations to increase or decrease. This periodic change is also reflected in the slow movement of the magnetic poles monitored through the various ground and satellite-based stations/instruments. The IRS of the aircraft also contains a variation program. It is supplied to the IRS true North to obtain a magnetic heading, which is ultimately fed to the FMS. The IRS is also normally recalibrated from time to time so that it can maintain the variation accurately enough. Lately, the magnetic pole location is changing more rapidly, approximately at a rate of 30 to 40 miles per year, moving towards Siberia. The need to continuously monitor and update the magnetic variation charts is, therefore, more crucial than ever. LO 061.01.03.01.05: Explain changes of variation with time and position.

An aircraft is following the flight log, and during the flight the wind has been as forecast. Between the M20 junction and the DET VOR, the pilot diverts from the route to avoid low clouds. By the 1:60 rule, the magnetic heading to fly to arrive at the DET VOR is...

key_points: The 1:60 rule states that: "For each degree of track error you will be one NM off-track having travelled 60 NM along track"
So, if you have travelled for 30 NM the error will be half NM per degree of track error or, if you have travelled for 20 NM, one third NM per degree of track error
If the track error is larger, the error will be proportionally larger, so 60 NM along track a 2o track error will place you 2 NM off track, or 1 NM off track after 30 NM
learning.explanation: The 1:60 rule states that: "For each degree of track error you will be one NM off-track having travelled 60 NM along track". So, if you have travelled for 30 NM the error will be half NM per degree of track error or, if you have travelled for 20 NM, one third NM per degree of track error. If the track error is larger, the error will be proportionally larger, so 60 NM along track a 2o track error will place you 2 NM off track, or 1 NM off track after 30 NM. The rule can be used to determine the track error angle,when the displacement is known, the displacement, when the track is known and correction to intercept, when displacement is known. The correction that must be made to intercept the DET VOR is given by the following formula, which is based on the 1:60 rule: (Distance off track / Miles to go) = (Degrees to intrercept / 60). Solving for Degrees to intercept we get: Degrees to intercept = (Distance off track x 60) / Miles to go = (2.5 NM x 60) / (27 NM - 15 NM) = 12.5o. Thus, since the aircraft is off-track to the left, the correction that must be made to arrive at DET VOR must be to the right, and its magnetic heading must be: Planned Magnetic Heading from M20 junction to DET VOR + Degrees to intercept = 283o (M) + 12.5o = 295.5o, which is very close to 296o.

content.question: What is the only true great circle on the surface of the WGS-84 ellipsoid?

options.B: The track along any meridian from pole to pole.
options.C: The great circle that is coincident with the Equator.

key_points: The planet of the Earth is roughly spherical
Because of its spin, it is slightly fatter at the Equator and slightly flattened at the poles, a shape known as an oblate spheroid or an ellipsoid
On the WGS-84 reference system, the Earth's shape is very close to this kind of ellipsoid
learning.explanation: The planet of the Earth is roughly spherical. Because of its spin, it is slightly fatter at the Equator and slightly flattened at the poles, a shape known as an oblate spheroid or an ellipsoid. On the WGS-84 reference system, the Earth's shape is very close to this kind of ellipsoid. The Prime Meridian and its anti-meridian form an ellipse which is not a great circle. Thus, the only true great circle on the surface of the WGS-84 ellipsoid is the great circle that is coincident with the Equator.

Before departure the ATIS at Buenos Aires airfield announces: Take Off Runway: 35W/V: 050°/20-30 kt Temperature: +20°C QNH: 1000 hPa On the airport chart for Buenos Aires the direction of runway 35 is given as 347° and the magnetic variation is 5°W.
Calculate the maximum Cross Wind Component for departure.

key_points: Wind directions True or Magnetic ? Any written meteorological information written (TAF, METAR, SIGMET, etc) will be given in true direction
Any information (ATIS, ATC) given to help pilot to line up the aircraft with runway for take-off or landing is magnetic, because runways directions are always magnetic
The wind velocity is made of two components, one acting along the runway called the headwind component, and the other acting across the runway called the crosswind component
learning.explanation: Wind directions True or Magnetic ? Any written meteorological information written (TAF, METAR, SIGMET, etc) will be given in true direction. Any information (ATIS, ATC) given to help pilot to line up the aircraft with runway for take-off or landing is magnetic, because runways directions are always magnetic. The wind velocity is made of two components, one acting along the runway called the headwind component, and the other acting across the runway called the crosswind component. It is possible to calculate the crosswind component taking the sine and the cosine of the relative bearing between the runway and the wind direction. Head/Tail wind component = Wind Speed x cosine (Relative Bearing) Crosswind component = Wind Speed x sine (Relative Bearing) Both indications are already magnetic, and and the worst scenario of wind speed is considered: Crosswind component = 30 x sine (347 - 50) = 27 kts

Using the actual GS experienced, what is the revised ETA at B?

key_points: Initially, with a GS of 115 kt, the aircraft would cover a distance of 75 NM in: 75 NM ÷ 115 kt = 0
learning.explanation: Initially, with a GS of 115 kt, the aircraft would cover a distance of 75 NM in: 75 NM ÷ 115 kt = 0.652 h 0.652 h x 60 min = 39.12 minutes However, the aircraft actually reached 75 NM 1.5 minutes later than initially planned. Meaning that, in reality, a distance of 75 NM was covered in 40.62 minutes (0.677 h). With this information, we are able to determine the actual GS: 75 NM ÷ 0.677 h = 110.8 kt Now that we know the actual GS (110.8 kt), we can calculate the time it will take to cover 250 NM: 250 NM ÷ 110.8 kt = 2.26 h (2 h 15 min) The aircraft departs A at 09:00 UTC, therefore the revised ETA at destination equals: 09:00 UTC + 2 h 15 min = 11:15 UTC

Note that question asks for the alteration to fly parallel to the intended track => 12º would only be correct if the question asked us to re-join our original track

In such case, we would have to find the track correction for the distance to go: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance to go TKE = (8 × 60) ÷ 80 TKE = 6º So turning 6° will parallel our track, and turning an extra 6° on top of that will direct us to the final destination

The Change of Latitude is the angle between the two parallels, measured at the centre of the Earth
To find the Change of Latitude: When the parallels of latitude are in different hemispheres - Add
learning.explanation: Latitude is measured as an angle from the Equator and the maximum latitude can be 90º North or 90º South. content.question: The value for variation changes with…

key_points: The poles of the Earth's magnetic field are close to the geographic poles, which lie on the axis of the Earth's rotation, but not coincident, so that a compass pointing to magnetic north will not point exactly at the geographic north pole
The angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian, or the difference between the true north and the magnetic north, is called variation and varies between 180o and zero

Because the Earth's magnetic pole is slowly moving around, the variation changes over time and therefore the date of any map showing variation is important, because if it is an old map, its variations will be incorrect
learning.explanation: The poles of the Earth's magnetic field are close to the geographic poles, which lie on the axis of the Earth's rotation, but not coincident, so that a compass pointing to magnetic north will not point exactly at the geographic north pole. The angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian, or the difference between the true north and the magnetic north, is called variation and varies between 180o and zero. Because the Earth's magnetic pole is slowly moving around, the variation changes over time and therefore the date of any map showing variation is important, because if it is an old map, its variations will be incorrect. Thus, the pilots should always fly with the most up-to-date chart for flight safety reasons. If the chart is republished at frequent intervals, the variation should be comparatively recent as well.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
What is the deviation when flying on a heading of 209°(C)?

key_points: When a magnetic needle is influenced only by the Earth’s magnetic field, it points to magnetic north

But, if the compass is installed in an aircraft, the Earth's magnetic field will be distorted by the metal and the electrical equipment around it and the needle now deviates slightly from magnetic north, indicating a direction of 000°, known as compass north
Deviation varies with magnetic latitude, aircraft heading and changes in aircraft electronic equipment
learning.explanation: When a magnetic needle is influenced only by the Earth’s magnetic field, it points to magnetic north. But, if the compass is installed in an aircraft, the Earth's magnetic field will be distorted by the metal and the electrical equipment around it and the needle now deviates slightly from magnetic north, indicating a direction of 000°, known as compass north. Deviation varies with magnetic latitude, aircraft heading and changes in aircraft electronic equipment. The difference between the direction of magnetic north and that of compass north is called "deviation". Deviation is measured in degrees and is described as "East" (+) or "West" (-). key_points: A freely suspended magnet will align itself with the Earth's magnetic field
The total field (T) is resolved into a horizontal component (H) and a vertical component (Z)

learning.explanation: A freely suspended magnet will align itself with the Earth's magnetic field. The total field (T) is resolved into a horizontal component (H) and a vertical component (Z). The horizontal component is the part which is detected by the compass needle in order to determine Magnetic North. The compass’ needle will align itself with the Earth's horizontal component (H) of the Earth's magnetic field. The compass is ineffective near the poles. As you approach the poles, the angle between magnetic flux and the horizon becomes vertical – compass ‘dip’ becomes a factor => decrease in horizontal magnetic field, increase in vertical magnetic field. The value of the horizontal component is maximum at the Magnetic Equator (=midway between the two poles). A freely suspended compass needle in the Earth's magnetic field will be horizontal to the Earth - in line with the horizontal component.

content.question:
An aircraft is passing point A at 12:05 with a GS of 140 kt. ETA at point B is 13:20. At 12:35, a deviation of 7 NM left of the intended track is noticed. To fly direct to point B from this point the pilot must change his/her track:
(Note: use 1:60 rule)

key_points: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning
If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track
The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good
learning.explanation: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning. If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track. The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good. The difference between them is called track error (TE). The angle at which we want to close to come back to the planned track is the closing angle (CA). The CA will depend how much further we want to rejoin the planned track. The 1 in 60 rule can be used to calculate the TE and the CA. TE = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 Planned track distance flown = 140 x 30’ = 70 NM TE = (7/70) x 60 = 6º The same 1 in 60 rule can be applied to calculate the CA. CA = (distance off-track/distance at which we want to rejoin track) x 60 Distance at which we want to rejoin track = 140 x 45’ = 105 NM CA = (7/105) x 60 = 4º With both TE and CA, we can determine by how much heading change we should apply to regain track: Heading change = TE + CA = 6º + 4º = 10º R The aircraft is left off-track, the aircraft must fly right to regain track.

content.question: The diameter of the Earth is approximately...

key_points: The diameter of Earth depends on where you are measuring it from
The Earth is not a perfect sphere, and so it has a different diameter around the equator than it does from pole to pole
We know that at the Equator, 1º Longitude = 1NM
learning.explanation: The diameter of Earth depends on where you are measuring it from. The Earth is not a perfect sphere, and so it has a different diameter around the equator than it does from pole to pole. We know that at the Equator, 1º Longitude = 1NM. Based on that, the circumference of the Earth may be calculated as follows: Earth circumference at the Equator = 360º x 60 NM = 21 600 NM => 21 600 NM x 1.852 = 40 000 km Circumference = π x diameter (π = 3.14) 40 000 km = π x diameter diameter = 40 000 km ÷ π diameter = 12 732 km Alternatively, you can just remember that the Earth's circumference (the distance all the way around the equator) is approximately 40 000 km (21 600 NM) and its diameter (the distance from one side to the other through Earth's center) is roughly 12 700 km.

learning.explanation: The aircraft covered the flight leg from SOPET to TORDU in: 06:46 - 06:34 = 12 min. So, its Actual Groundspeed will be: Leg distance / Leg time = (37 NM / 12 min) x 60 = 185 kt. So, the Flight time from TORDU via LOTOS to EBROX is: Leg distance / Actual GS = (26 NM + 14 NM) / 185 kt = 0.22 hr or 13 min. And, the fuel required from TORDU via LOTOS to EBROX will be: Actual fuel flow x Flight leg time = 2.5 lt/min x 13 min = 32.5 lt. Therefore, the new estimated remaining fuel at EBROX will be: Remaining fuel at TORDU - Fuel required from TORDU to EBROX = 385 lt - 32.5 lt = 352.5 lt, which is very close to 353 lt.

content.question: The BUN VOR/DME is located at 51°07'N,004°50'E where the variation is 0°. An aircraft is flying a true course of 090°, starting at 53°04'N, 003°37'E with the BUN turned on the VOR. When the VOR shows a radial of 360°, what is the range of the aircraft from the BUN?

key_points: Where Variation is 0o, the true meridians coincide with the magnetic ones
Radials are magnetic bearings emanated from VORs, so a 360o radial has a northerly magnetic direction
090° true course means that the aircraft flies eastwards and almost along the same parallel of latitude
learning.explanation: Where Variation is 0o, the true meridians coincide with the magnetic ones. Radials are magnetic bearings emanated from VORs, so a 360o radial has a northerly magnetic direction. 090° true course means that the aircraft flies eastwards and almost along the same parallel of latitude. Thus, its latitude (53°04'N) remains constant, when it crosses the R360 BUN. Variation is 0o, so R360 coincides with the true meridian 004°50'E, which passes through the BUN VOR. The range between the aircraft crossing R360 BUN and BUN VOR is equal to their the Change of Latitude. So, applying the rule "Same hemispheres, Subtract", the Change of Latitude along the true meridian or R360 is: 53o04’N - 51o07’N = 1o 57’ or 117’. We know, also, that "Along a meridian, 1’ corresponds to 1NM". Therefore, the range of the aircraft from the BUN VOR when crossing R360 is 117NM.

key_points: Latitude and longitude are the grid lines you see on globes
Longitude is the angle in the equatorial plane
There is no natural reference for longitude, but the zero line, called the "prime meridian", is taken, by convention, as the line through Greenwich England
learning.explanation: Latitude and longitude are the grid lines you see on globes. Longitude is the angle in the equatorial plane. There is no natural reference for longitude, but the zero line, called the "prime meridian", is taken, by convention, as the line through Greenwich England. For a spherical Earth, latitude and longitude are angles seen from the center of the Earth and only for the longitude is the exactly the same as for an ellipsoid Earth. Geodetic latitude and longitude is used to define a position on the WGS 84 ellipsoid for aviation charts. Geodetic longitude is defined as "The angular distance between the prime meridian and another meridian passing through a point on the Earth's surface" or "The angle in the equatorial plane between the line a that connects the Earth's centre with the prime meridian and the line b that connects the centre with the meridian on which the point lies". Because the vertex of the angle is the centre of the Earth, the same as for geocentric longitude, the value is the same for both types of longitude.

An aircraft has the following in flight conditions:
Altitude: FL140
IAS: 210 kts
OAT: -5°C
Wind component : -35 kts
When 150 NM from the reporting point, what IAS reduction is required to arrive 5 minutes later than planned?

key_points: To answer this question, we will need to find the groundspeed from the provided IAS
Thereafter, we are expected to find the new groundspeed required to arrive 5 minutes later than planned
Lastly, we will convert it back to IAS and determine the reduction
learning.explanation: To answer this question, we will need to find the groundspeed from the provided IAS. Thereafter, we are expected to find the new groundspeed required to arrive 5 minutes later than planned. Lastly, we will convert it back to IAS and determine the reduction. Step-by-step solution: (1) Determine TAS from IAS: First Step (1): Use the “AIR SPEED” window. Align 14 000 ft with -5ºC. Second Step (2): Find IAS 210 kt (inner scale, outer ring) and read the corresponding value of TAS 264 kt (outer scale). (2) Knowing the wind component and TAS, we can determine the ground speed: Wind component: -35 kt TAS: 264 kt Groundspeed = 264 kt – 35 kt = 229 kt (3) Calculate the time it would take to cover 150 NM at 229 kt: Time = Distance ÷ Speed Time = 150 NM ÷ 229 kt Time = 39.3 min (4) However, the aircraft is required to arrive 5 minutes later than planned. Therefore, we need to find the revised time: Revised time = 39.3 min + 5 min = 44.3 min (5) Determine the new groundspeed to meet the delay restriction: Groundspeed = (150 NM / 44.3 min) x 60 min = 203 kt (6) Considering the wind component and the groundspeed, calculate the revised TAS: Revised TAS = 203 kt + 35 kt = 238 kt (7) Determine IAS from TAS: First Step (1): Use the “AIR SPEED” window. Align 14 000 ft with -5ºC. Second Step (2): Find TAS 238 kt (outer scale) and read the corresponding value of IAS 188 kt (inner scale, outer ring). Reduction in IAS = initial IAS – new IAS Reduction in IAS = 210 kt – 188 kt = 22 kt

content.question: How might you go about cross-checking your aircraft's position using the Airborne Weather Radar (AWR)?

learning.explanation: There are two possible answers for this question. However, the option "By selecting a suitable echo from the display, obtaining the relative bearing and distance, and converting it into a true bearing to plot on the chart." has been confirmed by feedback to be correct in official exams. The pilot may take a relative bearing from an AWR display and would then use the aircraft heading to turn the relative heading into a magnetic or true bearing to. Thereafter, the reciprocal from the ground feature can be back-plotted as true or magnetic. On the other hand, putting the AWR into "mapping" mode allows the radar to reflect off surface features, which can give quite a good indication of the ground profile nearby. For instance, ground mapping radar can allow pilots to distinguish coastlines quite easily, as well as mountain ranges and sometimes even cities. To establish a fix, the pilots would place the AWR in mapping mode and/or tilt the radar down a lot, then look for echoes on the display that show these features, comparing that with a chart to get an idea of their position. It is certainly a skill, and not one that will be passed through the generations of pilots very well in the modern era, as it is almost useless these days. learning.explanation: No calculations are required for this question, because it asks for TAS and CAS “at some point during climb” and not at a specific altitude during descent. A usefool tool in determining the changing relationship between EAS, CAS, TAS and Mach in climbs and descents, below the tropopause, is the ECTM graphs. CAS can be considered to be identical to IAS. The ECTM graphs are used to determine what happens to the other three speeds when climbing or descending, whilst holding one speed constant, by drawing initially the parameter that is to be held constant as a vertical line and drawing, later, connecting lines to the remaining letters. content.question: Where on the Earth does the sunrise occur earlier and earlier every day?

key_points: If you consider the time of sunrise at different points on the Earth's surface, it quickly becomes clear that the Sun rises at different times at different longitudes, because of the rotation of the Earth and different latitudes, because of the tilt of the Earth's axis
The time of sunrise and sunset changes very little day by day (except at high latitudes) and both times vary with latitude and time of the year
The reason for the variation of the duration of the daytime and nighttime throughout the year, is the inclination of the Earth's axis of rotation to the ecliptic
learning.explanation: If you consider the time of sunrise at different points on the Earth's surface, it quickly becomes clear that the Sun rises at different times at different longitudes, because of the rotation of the Earth and different latitudes, because of the tilt of the Earth's axis. The time of sunrise and sunset changes very little day by day (except at high latitudes) and both times vary with latitude and time of the year. The reason for the variation of the duration of the daytime and nighttime throughout the year, is the inclination of the Earth's axis of rotation to the ecliptic. At the Equator, the length of the day and night varies very little and then only due to the differences between the mean solar day (which is used for time keeping) and the apparent time kept by the Sun. Hence, at the Equator the sunrise will always be close to 0600 LMT and the sunset close to 1800 LMT. At the spring and autumn equinoxes, the time of sunrise and the time of sunset is approximately the same at all latitudes (within a few minutes of 0600 LMT and 1800 LMT respectively). Thus, at mid-latitudes, such as 33°N, the sunrise occurs earlier and earlier every day.

content.question: An aircraft is flying inbound a VOR along radial 310° and experiences a drift of 10°R. If the Groundspeed is 415 kt, the True airspeed is 480 kt and variation is 7°W, calculate the wind direction (M) and speed.

key_points: Radial is a magnetic bearing extending from a VOR/VORTAC/TACAN
Drift is the angle difference from heading to track The aircraft flies along the radial 310° inbound a VOR, then its magnetic track is: 310° - 180° = 130°M
And since it drifts by 10oR, then its magnetic heading is: 130°M - 10o = 120oM
learning.explanation: Radial is a magnetic bearing extending from a VOR/VORTAC/TACAN. Drift is the angle difference from heading to track The aircraft flies along the radial 310° inbound a VOR, then its magnetic track is: 310° - 180° = 130°M. And since it drifts by 10oR, then its magnetic heading is: 130°M - 10o = 120oM. For this question using your Navigation/Flight computer, apply the following steps: Place the centre dot over the TAS 480 kt. Set the Magnetic heading 120o under the True Index. Put a mark where the 10o starboard drift and the Groundspeed 415 kt coincide. Rotate the circular bezel until the mark you have made is exactly below the centre dot on the 0o drift line. The magnetic wind direction is shown under the True Index 075o (M). The wind speed is the difference between the value under the centre dot and the value under the mark: 480 kt - 380 kt = 100 kt. Therefore, the magnetic wind direction and speed is: 075°(M)/100 kt. E6-B Flight Computer Procedure: We are given a GS of 415 kt and TAS of 480 kt, however the wind speed on the slide reaches a maximum of about 264 kt, we can still use the E6-B flight computer following these steps: If your E6-B flight computer includes a high-speed side, you can skip the following steps and proceed directly to the procedure below using the given GS and TAS values. Divide the GS and TAS by 5: GS: 415 kt / 5 = 83 kt TAS: 480 kt / 5 = 96 kt Now, with GS = 83 kt and TAS = 96 kt, proceed as follows: Multiply the calculated (steps below) wind velocity by 5. Calculation of Magnetic Wind Direction and Velocity: Position the slide until the ring aligns with the speed arc corresponding to the Ground Speed (83 kt). Rotate the transparent disk to align the Magnetic Track (130°) under the TRUE INDEX. Determine the Wind Correction Angle (WCA): With a Drift angle of 10° to the right, WCA = 10° left. With the ring on the Ground Speed (83 kt) arc, mark the point where the 10° left WCA intersects the True Airspeed (96 kt) arc. Rotate the transparent disk until the mark aligns with the centerline, ABOVE the ring, between the ring and the TRUE INDEX. Count the lines between the ring and the mark to determine the Wind Velocity. In this case, with the ring on the 83 kt arc and the mark on the 103 kt arc, Wind Velocity = 100 kt (103 - 83 = 20, 20 x 5 = 100). Read the Magnetic Wind Direction under the TRUE INDEX. In this case, the value is 075°, resulting in Magnetic Wind Direction = 075°.

learning.explanation: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T. In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole. The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located. Magnetic Direction, have as reference the Magnetic North Pole and is assigned an angular value of 000º M or 360º M. Variation is the angle between the True and Magnetic North and is assigned in degrees East or West of the True North. If the Magnetic North is west of the True North, westerly variation, the magnetic direction will have a higher angular value than the true direction. If the Magnetic North is east of the True North, easterly variation, the magnetic direction will have a lower angular value than the true direction. Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least The utility of a magnetic compass on the aircraft will depend on the accuracy of its response to the magnetic field of the earth. The metallic structure of the airplane, its engine and equipment can affect the accuracy of the compass, an effect called the compass deviation. Compass deviation is defined by the number of degrees by which unwanted magnetic fields deflect the compass from magnetic north indication (desired indication). Deviation (-) West – Compass Best Deviation (+) East – Compass Least Drift or drift angle, is the angular difference between the track of the aircraft across and it's heading. Always remember that the drift angle is always measured with reference to the heading. The heading is the direction in witch the the aircraft’s nose is pointing for. True Track is 300º with drift 8º R, means that TT is right of Heading 292º (T). True heading (T) Variation (V) Magnetic heading (M) Deviation (D) Compass heading (C) 292º 10ºW 302º 4ºW 306º

content.question: An island is observed to be 15° to the left of the aircraft’s longitudinal axis. The aircraft heading is 120°M, variation 17°W. The true bearing from the aircraft to the island is…

key_points: Relative bearing is the clockwise angle from the fore/aft axis of the aircraft to the station
QDR Aircraft’s Magnetic Bearing from the station (Radial); QDM Aircraft’s Magnetic bearing to the station; QTE Aircraft’s True Bearing from the station; QUJ Aircraft’s True Track to the station
NOTE: QDM is the reciprocal of QDR; QUJ is the reciprocal of QTE
learning.explanation: Relative bearing is the clockwise angle from the fore/aft axis of the aircraft to the station. QDR Aircraft’s Magnetic Bearing from the station (Radial); QDM Aircraft’s Magnetic bearing to the station; QTE Aircraft’s True Bearing from the station; QUJ Aircraft’s True Track to the station. NOTE: QDM is the reciprocal of QDR; QUJ is the reciprocal of QTE. Converting a Relative Bearing (RBI) into a True Bearing: Apply aircraft variation to the magnetic heading to get true heading. Add relative bearing to true heading in order to obtain true bearing TO the station If the answer comes to more than 360°(T), subtract 360. Take the reciprocal in order to get the True Bearing to plot FROM the station. QUJ = RBI + True Heading QTE = RBI + True Heading +180º To obtain a True Heading from the Magnetic Heading: True Heading (T) Variation (V) Magnetic Heading (M) Deviation (D) Compass Heading (C) 103º 17ºW 120º The relative bearing is always measured clockwise from the nose of the aircraft, 15º left is the same as RBI 345º. Aircraft’s True Track to the island, QUJ = 345º + 103º = 448º 448º - 360º = 88º (T)

content.question: A pilot during the pre-flight planning procedure uses an aeronautical chart to find the magnetic variation. Which statement is correct regarding the magnetic variation at a specific position?

options.A: Although the magnetic poles move over time, local variation remains constant.
options.B: Volcanic activity causes magnetic variation to increase, any given geographic area.
options.C: Magnetic variation changes over time, due to displacement of magnetic materials in the earth.
options.D: The rise of mean sea level due to global warming causes magnetic variation to increase or decrease.

key_points: The poles of the Earth's magnetic field are close to the geographic poles, which lie on the axis of the Earth's rotation, but not coincident, so that a compass pointing to magnetic north will not point exactly at the geographic north pole
The angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian, or the difference between the true north and the magnetic north, is called variation and varies between 180o and zero
Due to the dynamic nature of the earth’s interior, the magnetic field is constantly changing
learning.explanation: The poles of the Earth's magnetic field are close to the geographic poles, which lie on the axis of the Earth's rotation, but not coincident, so that a compass pointing to magnetic north will not point exactly at the geographic north pole. The angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian, or the difference between the true north and the magnetic north, is called variation and varies between 180o and zero. Due to the dynamic nature of the earth’s interior, the magnetic field is constantly changing. Since, the Earth's magnetic pole is slowly moving around, the variation changes over time and therefore the date of any map showing variation is important, because if it is an old map, its variations will be incorrect. The pilots should always fly with the most up-to-date chart for flight safety reasons. If the chart is republished at frequent intervals, the variation should be comparatively recent as well.

key_points: Wind directions True or Magnetic? Any written meteorological information written (TAF, METAR, SIGMET, etc) will be given in true direction
Any information (ATIS, ATC) given to help pilot to line up the aircraft with runway for take-off or landing is magnetic, because runways directions are always magnetic
Wind information given by the tower is already magnetic and the runway is also magnetic, no need to apply variation
learning.explanation: Wind directions True or Magnetic? Any written meteorological information written (TAF, METAR, SIGMET, etc) will be given in true direction. Any information (ATIS, ATC) given to help pilot to line up the aircraft with runway for take-off or landing is magnetic, because runways directions are always magnetic. Wind information given by the tower is already magnetic and the runway is also magnetic, no need to apply variation. The wind velocity is made of two components, one acting along the runway called the headwind component, and the other acting across the runway called the crosswind component. It is possible to calculate the crosswind component taking the sine and the cosine of the relative bearing between the runway and the wind direction. Head/Tail wind component = Wind Speed x cosine (Relative Bearing) Crosswind component = Wind Speed x sine (Relative Bearing) Wind information given by the tower is already magnetic and the runway is also magnetic, no need to apply variation. Head/Tail wind component = 26 x cosine (260º - 238º) = 24 kts Headwind ou tailwind ? visualize the track of the aircraft and from where is the wind coming from. content.question: What is the definition of the Geodetic Longitude?

options.A: The distance between the plane of the meridian that passes through a point on the surface of the ellipsoid and the plane of the anti-meridian.
options.B: The distance between the plane of the meridian that passes through a point on the surface of the ellipsoid and the plane of the prime meridian.
options.C: The angle between the plane of the meridian that passes through a point on the surface of the ellipsoid and the plane of the prime meridian.
options.D: The angle in the equatorial plane between the line a that connects the Earth's centre with the prime meridian and the line b that connects the centre with the anti-meridian of the point.

key_points: Latitude and longitude are the grid lines you see on globes
Longitude is the angle in the equatorial plane
There is no natural reference for longitude, but the zero line, called the "prime meridian", is taken, by convention, as the line through Greenwich England
learning.explanation: Latitude and longitude are the grid lines you see on globes. Longitude is the angle in the equatorial plane. There is no natural reference for longitude, but the zero line, called the "prime meridian", is taken, by convention, as the line through Greenwich England. For a spherical Earth, latitude and longitude are angles seen from the center of the Earth and only for the longitude is the exactly the same as for an ellipsoid Earth. Geodetic latitude and longitude is used to define a position on the WGS 84 ellipsoid for aviation charts. Geodetic longitude is defined as "The angular distance between the prime meridian and another meridian passing through a point on the Earth's surface" or "The angle in the equatorial plane between the line a that connects the Earth's centre with the prime meridian and the line b that connects the centre with the meridian on which the point lies". Because the vertex of the angle is the centre of the Earth, the same as for geocentric longitude, the value is the same for both types of longitude.

content.question: An aircraft when tracking inbound with a TAS of 150 kt onto a VOR on the 325° radial, experiences a drift of 10° right. The same aircraft after departure with a TAS of 150 kt tracks outbound on the 075° radial of the same VOR, experiencing a drift of 10° right. What is the wind velocity and direction (T°), if magnetic variation is 8° East?

key_points: Radial is a magnetic bearing extending from a VOR/VORTAC/TACAN
Drift is the angle difference from the aircraft’s heading to its actual track (track made good)
When tracking inbound on Radial 325°, then its magnetic track is: 325°M - 180° = 145°M
learning.explanation: Radial is a magnetic bearing extending from a VOR/VORTAC/TACAN. Drift is the angle difference from the aircraft’s heading to its actual track (track made good). When tracking inbound on Radial 325°, then its magnetic track is: 325°M - 180° = 145°M. Thus, its true track is: 145°M + 8° = 153°T (Variation East - Magnetic Least). And since it drifts by 10° right, its heading is: 153°T - 10° = 143°T. When tracking outbound on Radial 075°, then its magnetic track is 075°M and its true track: 075°M + 8 = 083°T (Variation East - Magnetic Least). And since it drifts by 10° right, its heading is: 083°T - 10° = 073°T. A method to assess the wind is to use the drift on different headings, known as multi-drift wind method: Place the centre dot over TAS 150 kt and put true heading 143°T under the True Index. Draw a line down the 10° right drift. Now put the next heading 073°T under the True Index and draw a line down the 10° right drift again. The point where the two drift lines intersect is the end of the wind vector. Rotate the disc until the intersection of the two drift lines is immediately under the centre dot on the 0° drift line. Read off the wind direction below the True Index as 028°T. And the wind speed is the difference between the value under the centre dot (150) and the value under the drift lines intersection (118): 150 kt - 118 kt = 32 kt. Thus, the wind velocity and direction (T°) is 028°/32 kt.

Variation is the angle between the True and Magnetic North and is assigned in degrees East or West of the True North. If the Magnetic North is west of the True North, westerly variation, the magnetic direction will have a higher angular value than the true direction. If the Magnetic North is east of the True North, easterly variation, the magnetic direction will have a lower angular value than the true direction. Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least The utility of a magnetic compass on the aircraft will depend on the accuracy of its response to the magnetic field of the earth. The metallic structure of the airplane, its engine and equipment can affect the accuracy of the compass, an effect called the compass deviation. Compass deviation is defined by the number of degrees by which unwanted magnetic fields deflect the compass from magnetic north indication (desired indication). Deviation (-) West – Compass Best Deviation (+) East – Compass Least

content.question:
While proceeding en route, after half the distance between two waypoints, the aircraft’s position is 3 NM left of the desired track. The total distance between the two waypoints is 120 NM.
Using the 1 sin 60 rule and for the purpose of reaching the active waypoint, the heading should be changed by…

key_points: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning
If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track
The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good
learning.explanation: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning. If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track. The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good. The difference between them is called track error (TE). The angle at which we want to close to come back to the planned track is the closing angle (CA). The CA will depend how much further we want to rejoin the planned track. The 1 in 60 rule can be used to calculate the TE and the CA. TE = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 TE = (3/60) x 60 = 3º The same 1 in 60 rule can be applied to calculate the CA. CA = (distance off-track/distance at which we want to rejoin track) x 60 CA = (3/60) x 60 = 3º With both TE and CA, we can determine by how much heading change we should apply to regain track: Heading change = TE + CA = 3º + 3º = 6º R The aircraft is left off-track, the aircraft must fly right to regain track.

New Ground Speed = (65 NM / 30 min) x 60 = 130 kt

content.question: Over a period of couple of days it is observed that the duration of the daylight is longer and the sun tends to rise earlier. Time of the year is not close to the equinoxes. Where could this happen?

key_points: The axis of rotation of the Earth is inclined to its orbital elliptical path around the Sun at an angle of about 66
5o, which means that the angle between the plane of ecliptic and the Earth's equator is 23
5o
learning.explanation: The axis of rotation of the Earth is inclined to its orbital elliptical path around the Sun at an angle of about 66.5o, which means that the angle between the plane of ecliptic and the Earth's equator is 23.5o. The Sun will be exactly overhead 23.5o N in June, when "the northern hemisphere summer solstice" takes place and we have the longest day. Also, it will be overhead 23.5o S in December, when "the northern hemisphere winter solstice" will take place and we will have the longest night. The latitudes 23.5o N and 23.5o S are called the Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn respectively and represent the highest latitudes where the Sun will be directly overhead. The tilt of the Earth's axis is responsible for the longer nights in winter and the longer days in summer. It also means that in extreme northern and southern latitudes, there will be times of the year in winter when the Sun does not rise and times in summer when it does not set. Between the solstices are the Equinoxes, when the Sun is passing over the Equator, where night and day are of equal length. The equinoxes are the times when the relative length of night and day and the elevation of the noon sun, known as the declination of the Sun, are changing at the greatest rate. If you consider the time of sunrise at different points on the Earth's surface, it quickly becomes clear that the Sun rises at different times at different longitudes, because of the rotation of the Earth and different latitudes, because of the tilt of the Earth's axis. The time of sunrise and sunset changes very little day by day (except at high latitudes) and both times vary with latitude and time of the year. The reason for the variation of the duration of the daytime and nighttime throughout the year, is the inclination of the Earth's axis of rotation to the ecliptic. At the Equator, the length of the day and night varies very little and then only due to the differences between the mean solar day (which is used for time keeping) and the apparent time kept by the Sun. Hence, at the Equator the sunrise will always be close to 0600 LMT and the sunset close to 1800 LMT. At the spring and autumn equinoxes, the time of sunrise and the time of sunset is approximately the same at all latitudes (within a few minutes of 0600 LMT and 1800 LMT respectively).

content.question: A definition of a Magnetic Track angle is:

options.A: The direction of a line referenced to the isogonic line to the Magnetic North pole. Compass North.
options.B: The direction of a line referenced to Magnetic North.
options.C: The direction of the longitudinal axis of an aircraft referenced to Magnetic North.
options.D: The direction of the longitudinal axis of an aircraft referenced to Compass North.

key_points: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T
In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole
The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located
learning.explanation: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T. In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole. The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located. Magnetic Direction, have as reference the Magnetic North Pole and is assigned an angular value of 000º M or 360º M. Variation is the angle between the True and Magnetic North and is assigned in degrees East or West of the True North. If the Magnetic North is west of the True North, westerly variation, the magnetic direction will have a higher angular value than the true direction. If the Magnetic North is east of the True North, easterly variation, the magnetic direction will have a lower angular value than the true direction. Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least The utility of a magnetic compass on the aircraft will depend on the accuracy of its response to the magnetic field of the earth. The metallic structure of the airplane, its engine and equipment can affect the accuracy of the compass, an effect called the compass deviation. Compass deviation is defined by the number of degrees by which unwanted magnetic fields deflect the compass from magnetic north indication (desired indication). Deviation (-) West – Compass Best Deviation (+) East – Compass Least

96o, rounded 3o

content.question: An aircraft is departing from an airport which has an elevation of 2000 ft and the QNH is 1003 hPa. The TAS is 100 kt, the head wind component is 20 kt and the rate of climb is 1000 ft/min. Top of climb is FL 100. At what distance from the airport will this be achieved?

key_points: (1) Convert True Altitude into Pressure Altitude: 1013 hPa - 1003 hPa = 10 hPa Assuming 30 ft/hPa: 10 hPa x 30 ft/hPa = 300 ft Local QNH is lower than standard pressure => pressure altitude is higher than true altitude: 2 000 ft + 300 ft = 2 300 ft (2) Determine change in Height: Climbing from 2 300 ft to 10 000 ft equals a change in height of 7 700 ft
(3) Calculate time to climb 7 700 ft at a rate of climb of 1 000 ft/min: 7 700 ft ÷ 1 000 ft/min = 7
7 min (4) Calculate Ground distance: Ground speed = TAS - headwind Ground speed = 100 kt - 20 kt = 80 kt Ground distance = (80 kt x 7
learning.explanation: (1) Convert True Altitude into Pressure Altitude: 1013 hPa - 1003 hPa = 10 hPa Assuming 30 ft/hPa: 10 hPa x 30 ft/hPa = 300 ft Local QNH is lower than standard pressure => pressure altitude is higher than true altitude: 2 000 ft + 300 ft = 2 300 ft (2) Determine change in Height: Climbing from 2 300 ft to 10 000 ft equals a change in height of 7 700 ft. (3) Calculate time to climb 7 700 ft at a rate of climb of 1 000 ft/min: 7 700 ft ÷ 1 000 ft/min = 7.7 min (4) Calculate Ground distance: Ground speed = TAS - headwind Ground speed = 100 kt - 20 kt = 80 kt Ground distance = (80 kt x 7.7 min) / 60 min Ground distance = 10.3 NM Note that it is the same to convert airfield altitude to pressure altitude or FL100 to True altitude.

For this question, you may apply simple trigonometry to find the headwind component: The Headwind component (HWC) is: Wind speed x Cos of the Angle difference between Average TT and Wind True direction = 25 kt x Cos 30° = 21.6 kt. learning.explanation: Climb Gradient is the ratio of the height gained for a given horizontal distance, in the same units of measurement, expressed as a percentage. Rate of Climb is the aircraft's vertical speed, the height gained per unit of time, usually expressed in feet per minute. Considering an aircraft in a steady climb, the minimum vertical speed in ft/min is given by the formula: Rate of Climb = Climb Gradient(%) x GS x 6080 / 6000. Thus, for a climb gradient of 6.6% and a Groundspeed of 180 kt, the Rate of Climb will be: Rate of Climb (ft/min) = 6.6 % x 180 kt x 6080 / 6000 = 1 204 ft/min, which is very close to 1 188 ft/min.

The points are in different hemispheres
learning.explanation: The two points lie on the same parallel of latitude. So, the distance between them is given by the formula: Departure (NM) = Change of Longitude (minutes) x Cosine of Latitude. The points are in different hemispheres. So, to get the Change of Longitude, add their longitudes: 173°25' + 166°12' = 339° 37'. content.question: A pilot is flying VFR in VMC at 1 500 ft above ground, passing small separated villages. The pilot chose a church tower in such a village as a turning point for a new course. After completing the turn and flying towards the next waypoint, which is shown on the chart as a framework tower, the pilot is not able to find this tower at the expected time overhead. What is a likely reason for this navigation error?

options.A: The pilot changed course at a wrong village.
options.B: The vertical visibility was not sufficient to recognize the waypoints.
options.C: It is hard to recognize church towers in villages.
options.D: The framework tower is hidden behind buildings of the same height.

key_points: Visual navigation is the use of topographical maps to monitor or fix the aircraft's position
Map reading is the determination of aircraft's position, by matching natural or built-up features with their corresponding symbols on a chart

Map reading actually consists of two related, but different skills: Map to ground navigation for flight monitoring, where the pilot must be able to visualise the terain and physical features from symbols on the map
learning.explanation: Visual navigation is the use of topographical maps to monitor or fix the aircraft's position. Map reading is the determination of aircraft's position, by matching natural or built-up features with their corresponding symbols on a chart. Map reading actually consists of two related, but different skills: Map to ground navigation for flight monitoring, where the pilot must be able to visualise the terain and physical features from symbols on the map. Ground to map navigation, when the aircraft's position is uncertain, where the ground features must be turned into a mentally perceived picture of the map and related to the map symbols. The choice of the ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps do not necessarily show up well from the air. The rule for choosing a ground feature is to find something as unique as possible, such as masts, railways, rivers, bridges, etc. Also, the map to ground technique is recommended to avoid confirmation bias, for instance spotting a tower on the ground and convincing yourself that it is the church tower you would dearly like it to be on the map. For this question, the pilot chose ground features (towers, villages) as turning points, which are identical with many others and can cause confusion to the pilot's flight monitoring. Also, VFR navigation at lower levels, as in our case 1500 ft above ground, restricts the view ahead and around by the next fold of high ground and objects may only appear when you are close to them and when they are not obscured by high ground. Probably, the pilot changed course at a wrong village, because of his/her low cruise altitude and not recommended ground features choice.

content.question: An aircraft flies from A to B, the ground distance is 78 NM. After 48 NM the pilot notices a cross-track error angle of 5° to the right. In order to directly reach point B, by using the “1 in-60” rule, the pilot should change the heading to the left by...

key_points: By altering the heading towards the original track (to the left) by 5°, the aircraft will fly parallel to the original track
To re-join the original track at A, we must find the track correction to reach B
For that, we need to find the distance off-track first
learning.explanation: By altering the heading towards the original track (to the left) by 5°, the aircraft will fly parallel to the original track. To re-join the original track at A, we must find the track correction to reach B. For that, we need to find the distance off-track first. We have been given the Track Angle Error (TKE) of 5º to the right. We can determine the distance off track by applying the following formula: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track 5º = (distance off track × 60) ÷ 48 distance off track = (5º x 48) ÷ 60 = 4 NM The correction to reach B will be: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance to go TKE = (4 × 60) ÷ 30 TKE = 8° ⇒ Turning 5º to the left will lead us to fly parallel to the original track. Turning an extra 8° to the left will direct us to "B". 5° + 8° = 13° to the left to go direct to "B".

key_points: The aircraft is not in the desired track because the actual wind is different from the forecasted wind
This exercise is asking us to determine the actual wind, and we will solve it using with the flight computer
To determine the actual wind we need the information related to actual path of aircraft over the ground, G/S and actual track and as well the TAS and actual heading information
learning.explanation: The aircraft is not in the desired track because the actual wind is different from the forecasted wind. This exercise is asking us to determine the actual wind, and we will solve it using with the flight computer. To determine the actual wind we need the information related to actual path of aircraft over the ground, G/S and actual track and as well the TAS and actual heading information. Based on the forecasted wind, and using the flight computer we can determine the aircraft planned heading and G/S. Solving from Heading (HDG), knowing WV, TAS and required track. Set wind direction to 270º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 190 kt. Mark the wind velocity 25 kt down from the centre point. Initially, set the True Track to 355º under the "TRUE HEADING" index. Note that this heading would result in 7ºR drift and a track of 362º. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 355º. This occurs at a heading of 348º with 7ºR drift. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 186 kt. At a ground speed of 186 kt, after 30 min of flight, the distance covered should be 93 NM. However, according to the question text, tha aircraft is 4.5 NM ahead = 97.5 NM. Therefore, the actual ground speed = 97.5 NM x 2 = 195 kt To determine the actual track over the ground, we will calculate the actual TKE and add it to the planned track. TEK = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 TEK = ( 3,5 / (93 + 4,5) ) x 60 = 2ºR 2º right means that the actual track of the aircraft over the ground is 355º + 2º = 357º Knowing the GS 195 kt, TAS 190 kt, heading 348º and track 357º, it is possible to determine the actual wind using the flight computer by following the steps below: Determining winds with the flight computer: Set True Heading (348ºT) under "True Index" Place centre dot over TAS (190 kts) Mark the point where drift (9ºR) and GS (195 kt) meet. content.question: What is the density altitude, given a pressure altitude of FL55 and a static air temperature of +33°C?

key_points: Note: This should not be a GNAV question
Density altitude is not particularly important to GNAV specifically, and calculating it is not part of the GNAV learning objectives, so you should appeal this question if you see it in a GNAV exam
Feedback from one authority shows that has been seen in this exam
learning.explanation: Note: This should not be a GNAV question. Density altitude is not particularly important to GNAV specifically, and calculating it is not part of the GNAV learning objectives, so you should appeal this question if you see it in a GNAV exam. Feedback from one authority shows that has been seen in this exam. Density altitude is a measure of the environmental air density, in comparison to where you would find that same density in the International Standard Atmosphere (ISA), so you end up with an altitude measurement. A high density altitude means low air density, and a low density altitude means high air density (what you would get at low-level). Density altitude can be calculated in 2 main ways, by flight computer or by mathematical calculation. By flight computer (CRP-5) it is relatively simple, in the "AIR SPEED" window, line up the pressure altitude with the OAT, and read off the density altitude in the "DENSITY ALTITUDE" window (x1000 ft). In this case, you get just under 9000 ft, but this is not the most accurate measurement in the world. We could show a picture in the annex, but flight computers are each very slightly different, so different answers could easily be found on different computers. By mathematical calculation, you take the pressure altitude, and adjust it for temperature by 120 ft per °C different from ISA. As high temperature is lower density, this means that higher than ISA temperature means a higher density altitude, and lower than ISA temperature means a lower density altitude. ISA temperature at 5500 ft (FL55) is 15 - 2(5.5) = 4°C, so with an OAT of +33°C, we are at ISA +29°C, meaning our density altitude is higher than our pressure altitude. The difference is 120 ft/°C x 29°C = 3480 ft, so the Density altitude is 5500 + 3480 = 8980 ft, closest answer 9000 ft

content.question: An aircraft is cruising at FL410, Mach 0.86. The ISA deviation is -12ºC. What is the TAS of the aircraft?

learning.explanation: Mach number can be calculated using the following formula: M = TAS / LSS Where M stands Mach number and LSS is local speed of sound. The Local Speed of Sound is only dependent on absolute temperature and can be calculated as follows: LSS = 38.95 x √ K T(K) = ºC + 273 (1) Determine the OAT at FL410: ISA temperature at FL410 = -56.5ºC ISA dev = -12ºC Thus, OAT = - 56.5 - 12 = -68.5ºC (1) Convert ºC into K: K = -68.5ºC + 273 = 204.5 K (2) Calculate LSS: LSS = 38.95 x √204.5 = 557 kt (3) Determine the Mach number: TAS = ? kt LSS = 557 kt M = 0.86 0.86 = TAS / 557 kt = 479 kt Note: In an International Standard Atmosphere (ISA) atmosphere, the temperature declines by 2°C for every 1 000 ft of ascent until reaching the Tropopause, which occurs at an altitude of 36,000 feet. Beyond this point, the temperature is considered constant and remains at -56.5°C.

The True course in the flight log is 270°, the forecast wind is 045°T/15 kt and the TAS is 150 kt. After 15 minutes of flying with the planned TAS and TH the aircraft is 2 NM north of the intended track and 2.5 NM ahead of the dead reckoning position.
