Note that this heading would result in 4ºL drift and a track of 266º. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading minus the drift gives a track of 270º. This occurs at a heading of 274º with 4ºL drift. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 160 kt. It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning. If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track. The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good. The difference between them is called track error (TE). The angle at which we want to close to come back to the planned track is the closing angle (CA). The CA will depend how much further we want to rejoin the planned track. The 1 in 60 rule can be used to calculate the TE and the CA. TE = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 GS = 160 kts Planned track distance flown = 160 x 15’ = 40 NM => This distance is based on the forecast wind, but the exercise states that the aircraft is 2.5 ahead of the dead reckoning position, actual position = 40 + 2.5 = 42.5 NM. TE = (2/42.5) x 60 = approx. 3º

content.question: An aircraft with a constant TAS of 180 kt, initially follows a magnetic track of 250°M, because of a drift 8°L. After turning, it follows a magnetic track of 340°M, because of a drift 8°R. What is the wind velocity and direction (T°), if magnetic variation is 10° East?

key_points: Radial is a magnetic bearing extending from a VOR/VORTAC/TACAN
Drift is the angle difference from the aircraft’s heading to its actual track (track made good)
When following a magnetic track of 250°M, its true track is: 250°M + 10°E = 260°T (Variation East - Magnetic Least)
learning.explanation: Radial is a magnetic bearing extending from a VOR/VORTAC/TACAN. Drift is the angle difference from the aircraft’s heading to its actual track (track made good). When following a magnetic track of 250°M, its true track is: 250°M + 10°E = 260°T (Variation East - Magnetic Least). And since it drifts by 8° Left, its heading is: 260°T + 8° = 268°T. When following a magnetic track of 340°M, its true track is: 340°M + 10°E = 350°T (Variation East - Magnetic Least). And since it drifts by 8° Right, its heading is: 350°T - 8° = 342°T. A method to assess the wind is to use the drift on different headings, known as multi-drift wind method: Place the centre dot over TAS 180 kt and put true heading 268°T under the True Index. Draw a line down the 8° left drift. Now put the next heading 342°T under the True Index and draw a line down the 8° right drift again. The point where the two drift lines intersect is the end of the wind vector. Rotate the disc until the intersection of the two drift lines is immediately under the centre dot on the 0° drift line. Read off the wind direction below the True Index as 305°T. And the wind speed is the difference between the value under the centre dot (180) and the value under the drift lines intersection (144): 180 kt - 144 kt = 36 kt. Thus, the wind velocity and direction (T°) is 305°/ 36 kt.

key_points: The heights on the glideslope can be calculted using the formula: Height difference (ft) = Glidepath Angle(o) x Distance to go (ft) / 60

So, solving for Distance to go, we get: Distance to go (ft) = (Height difference (ft) x 60) / Glidepath angle (o). The aircraft descends from cruise altitude 5 500 ft to the traffic pattern altitude 2 000 ft, thus the height difference is 3 500 ft. Therefore, the horizontal distance covered during the descent is: Distance to go (ft) = (3 500 ft x 60) / 3° = 70 000 ft or 70 000 ft / 6 080 = 11.51 NM, rounded 12 NM. The aircraft's average Rate of Descent is 750 ft/min, which means that it loses 750 ft in 1 min. Therefore, the aircraft loses 3 500 ft in: 3 500 ft / 750 ft/min = 4.67 minutes or 4 minutes 40 seconds. Finally, the aircraft to reach downwind from cruise altitude 5 500 ft to the traffic pattern altitude 2 000 ft following a 3° glidepath angle, the descent must be initiated at 12 NM prior to downwind, and with a Rate of Descent of 750 ft/min, it will last for 4 minutes 40 seconds.

learning.explanation: Deviation is called the difference between the direction of magnetic north and that of compass north. The deviation experienced is specific to each aircraft and varies with heading and magnetic latitude. The variation with heading occurs because sometimes the resultant aircraft fields will oppose the Earth's field and sometimes reinforce them. Which heading this occurs on, depends on how the deviating fields are aligned within the aircraft. The variation with magnetic latitude occurs because the horizontal component of the Earth's magnetic field varies in strength depending where it is detected. At the magnetic equator, all the field is in the horizontal component, at the poles the horizontal component is weak to non-existent. Where the horizontal component is weak, the deviating forces are proportionally stronger and therefore the amount of deviation is greater near the poles and correspondingly less at the magnetic equator.

content.question: The distance between geodetic parallels of latitude on the surface of the WGS 84 ellipsoid…

key_points: The Earth is roughly spherical
Because of its spin it is slightly fatter at the equator and slightly flattened at the poles, a shape known as an oblate spheroid or an ellipsoid
You might come across the term "Geoid"
learning.explanation: The Earth is roughly spherical. Because of its spin it is slightly fatter at the equator and slightly flattened at the poles, a shape known as an oblate spheroid or an ellipsoid. You might come across the term "Geoid". In geodesy, a reference ellipsoid is a mathematically defined surface that approximates the geoid. Because of their relative simplicity, reference ellipsoids are used as a preferred surface on which geodetic network computations are performed and point coordinates such as latitude, longitude and elevation are defined. Modern navigation systems, like GPS, ude these reference systems and the most common of these is the World Geodetic System of 1984 or WGS 84, created by the United States military. Geodetic latitude and longitude is used to define a position on the WGS 84 ellipsoid for aviation charts. Geodetic latitude is the angle that a line drawn perpendicular to the surface through a point on a spheroid makes with the equatorial plane (plumb-line on the ellipsoid) and is other than the geocentric (earth centred) latitude. Despite the fact that, in general navigation, we assume that one degree of latitude along a meridian equals to 60 nm. In fact, using a WGS84 ellipsoid, one degree of latitude has a length of 59.7 nm (110.574 km) at the equator and increases progressively with increasing latitude up to 60.3 nm (111.694 km) at the poles.

content.question: Which statement about meridians is correct?

options.A: The plane of a meridian is parallel to the Equator.
options.B: All meridians are parallel to the Greenwich Meridian.
options.C: A meridian and its anti-meridian form a complete great circle.
options.D: A meridian is a complete great circle of 360°.

key_points: A great circle is the largest possible circle that can be drawn around a sphere
All spheres have great circles
If you cut a sphere at one of its great circles, you'd cut it exactly in half
learning.explanation: A great circle is the largest possible circle that can be drawn around a sphere. All spheres have great circles. If you cut a sphere at one of its great circles, you'd cut it exactly in half. A great circle has the same circumference, or outer boundary, and the same centre point as its sphere. The geometry of spheres is useful for mapping the Earth and other planets. The Earth is not a perfect sphere, but it maintains the general shape. All the meridians on Earth are parts great circles. Meridian and its anti meridian for a great circle. Meridians, including the prime meridian, are the north-south lines we use to help describe exactly where we are on the Earth. All these lines of longitude meet at the poles, cutting the Earth neatly in half. The Equator is another of the Earth's great circles. If you were to cut into the Earth right on its Equator, you'd have two equal halves: the Northern and Southern Hemispheres. The Equator is the only east-west line that is a great circle. All other parallels (lines of latitude) get smaller as you get near the poles. Great circles can be found on spheres as big as planets and as small as oranges. If you cut an orange exactly in half, the line you cut is the orange's great circle. And until you eat one or both halves, you have two equal hemispheres of the same orange. Great circles are also useful in planning routes. The shortest path between two points on the surface of a sphere is always a segment of a great circle. Plotting great circles comes in very handy for airplane pilots trying to fly the shortest distance between two points.

content.question: In navigation we assume that the shape of earth is..

key_points: Shape Of the Earth The Earth is almost completely round
The force of gravity would pull the Earth into a perfect sphere shape, but its fast rotation on its axis reduces the effect of gravity on the Equator
The Earth rotates rapidly every 24 h and the surface at the Equator moves os fast that the effect of gravity is reduced there
learning.explanation: Shape Of the Earth The Earth is almost completely round. The force of gravity would pull the Earth into a perfect sphere shape, but its fast rotation on its axis reduces the effect of gravity on the Equator. The Earth rotates rapidly every 24 h and the surface at the Equator moves os fast that the effect of gravity is reduced there. This reduced gravity causes the land around the Equator to bulge outwards by approximately 21 km, while making the land at the poles appear flattened. The Earth is, therefore, an irregularly shaped ellipsoid, which is flattened at the poles and bulges at the Equator. This is slightly squished shape is called geoid. For most navigational purposes the Earth is assumed to be a perfect sphere (for simplicity).

If we alter our heading by 3.3° (towards the original track) we will parallel our original track. In order to re-join the original track, we must calculate the track correction for the distance to go: Distance to go = 80 NM - 73 NM = 7 NM TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track TKE = (4 × 60) ÷ 7 TKE = 34° (approx.) Therefore, 3° + 34° = 37º (approx.) would be the total alteration required (to re-join the original track). The deviation was to the right, therefore we must fly 37º to the left. content.question: The circumference of the Earth is approximately...

key_points: The diameter of Earth depends on where you are measuring it from
The Earth is not a perfect sphere, and so it has a different diameter around the equator than it does from pole to pole
We know that at the Equator, 1º Longitude = 1NM
learning.explanation: The diameter of Earth depends on where you are measuring it from. The Earth is not a perfect sphere, and so it has a different diameter around the equator than it does from pole to pole. We know that at the Equator, 1º Longitude = 1NM. Based on that, the circumference of the Earth may be calculated as follows: Earth circumference at the Equator = 360º x 60 NM = 21 600 NM => 21 600 NM x 1.852 = 40 000 km Circumference = π x diameter (π = 3.14) 40 000 km = π x diameter diameter = 40 000 km ÷ π diameter = 12 732 km Alternatively, you can just remember that the Earth's circumference (the distance all the way around the equator) is approximately 40 000 km (21 600 NM) and its diameter (the distance from one side to the other through Earth's center) is roughly 12 700 km.

content.question:
A pilot is planned to fly a track of 270°(T) towards ZVR VOR. At 10:20 UTC they plot their position and determine that they are on course. At 10:32 UTC, after having travelled for 60 NM, the pilot plots their position again and finds themselves 10 NM off-track towards the south. Given the following information, calculate their average drift from 10:20 UTC to 10:32 UTC.
TAS: 280 kt
Forecast Wind: 150º/30 kt

key_points: Solving from Heading (HDG), knowing WV, TAS and required track
Set wind direction to 150º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top
Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 280 kt
learning.explanation: Solving from Heading (HDG), knowing WV, TAS and required track. Set wind direction to 150º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 280 kt. Mark the wind velocity 30 kt down from the centre point. Initially, set the True Track to 270º under the "TRUE HEADING" index. Note that this heading would result in 5ºR drift and a track of 275º. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 270º. This occurs at a heading of 265º with 5ºR drift. All this means is that, to counteract an expected drift of 5ºR, the aircraft flew a heading of 265º(T). However, after covering a distance of 60 NM, our track error angle is 10º left, meaning our track made good has been 260º (T) Calculating the difference between our heading and the track made good results in 5º to the left (265ºT to 260ºT). The average drift observed from 10:20 UTC to 10:32 UTC amounts to 5º to the left. Note: Drift or drift angle, is the angular difference between the track of the aircraft across and it's heading. Always remember that the drift angle is always measured with reference to the heading.

content.question:
When flying a VFR map-reading exercise, the pilot becomes lost because of isolated patches of fog hindering the ability to accurately pin-point his/her position. Which of the following should the pilot do in this situation ?
1. Maintain visual contact with the ground.
2. Communicate, if in contact with an Air Traffic Control (ATC) unit, to request assistance.
3. Fly a series of expanding circles to find a suitable check point.
4. Look at the terrain for hills and valleys or line features such as a motorway, railway, river or coastline.
5. Read the map from map to ground.

key_points: As soon as the position of the aircraft is in doubt or lost, then: 1
Note the time
learning.explanation: As soon as the position of the aircraft is in doubt or lost, then: 1. Note the time. 2. Communicate, if in contact with an Air Traffic Control (ATC) unit, to request assistance. 3. Consider using any radio-navigation aids that may be available to give position information. 4. If short of fuel or near controlled airspace and not in contact with ATC, set 121.5 MHz and make a PAN call. 5. If that is not necessary, check the directional indicator (DI) and compass are still synchronised and continue to fly straight and level and on route plan heading. Thus, statement 3 is incorrect. 6. Estimate the distance travelled since the last known position. 7. Compare the ground with your estimated position on the map. When the aircraft’s position is uncertain, ground features must be turned into a mentally perceived picture of the map and related to the map symbols. This is “ground to map”. Thus, statement 5 is incorrect. 8. Once the position has been re-established, keep checking the heading and continue the flight by updating the estimated position regularly while looking for unique features such as hills, valleys, lakes, wood, built-up areas, rivers, coastlines, motorways and railways. In all cases, maintain VMC and visual contact with the ground, note the fuel state and try to identify an area suitable for a precautionary landing.

content.question: The pilot of a piston-engined aeroplane, flying a VFR flight and approaching to the last turning point, realizes that he/she is both a few minutes behind schedule and low on fuel. What is the appropriate action that should be taken?

options.A: Make an emergency landing at the nearest suitable field.
options.B: Turn before the scheduled turning point and fly directly to the destination.
options.C: Fly to a lower altitude to increase the TAS and decrease the HWC.
options.D: Orbit and contact ATC to receive further instructions.

key_points: When a pilot realizes that he/she is behind schedule, most probably either a stronger headwind, or less tailwind or just headwind (in case calm wind was expected) is experienced
This situation will decrease the Groundspeed and as a consequence both the required total flight time and the total fuel consumption will increase
The fuel amount to cater for things that don't go to plan, such as stronger headwinds, re-routing, a flight level other than expected, is called "Contingency fuel"
learning.explanation: When a pilot realizes that he/she is behind schedule, most probably either a stronger headwind, or less tailwind or just headwind (in case calm wind was expected) is experienced. This situation will decrease the Groundspeed and as a consequence both the required total flight time and the total fuel consumption will increase. The fuel amount to cater for things that don't go to plan, such as stronger headwinds, re-routing, a flight level other than expected, is called "Contingency fuel". Also, any aircraft must be landed with at least the Final Reserve Fuel in its tanks. If it looks like that it will land with less than Final Reserve Fuel, EU OPS says that the pilot must declare an emergency. But, for this question the Contingency fuel may not be sufficient and so as to avoid any consumption of the Final Reserve Fuel while being still on the air before landing, the best action is to reduce, as much as possible, the remaining ground distance and flight time until the destination, by turning before the scheduled turning point and flying directly to the destination, provided that the ATC is informed of the pilot's intentions accordingly and no safety issues emerge. An emergency landing at the nearest suitable field may pose at risk both the passengers and the aircraft and would be recommended in case the remaining fuel was not sufficient to reach at any other suitable airfield. Flying to a lower altitude would decrease the TAS and the Groundspeed, thus the required flight time and fuel to destination would increase. Any orbit would further increase the flight time and total fuel consumption until destination. Further instructions from the ATC should be asked while continuing towards the destination without wasting flight time.

content.question: A pilot has planned a navigation flight for daytime hours, but flies it at night. What is the most significant hazard of this flight?

options.C: Difficulty in identifying landmarks and reference points.
options.D: Increased risk associated with optical obstacles such as tail masts at night compared to daytime.

key_points: While planning a VFR navigation flight for daytime, natural landmarks such as roads, rivers, and towns might be selected to be used as visual cues
However, at night the visibility of these features is reduced or even impossible, making it challenging for the pilots to follow the original flight plan based on daytime visual references

The limited visibility at night might cause difficulty to the pilots in identifying landmarks and reference points to verify the position of the aircraft and cross-check the aircraft track, thus there is a danger of flying into terrain in the case of being lost
learning.explanation: While planning a VFR navigation flight for daytime, natural landmarks such as roads, rivers, and towns might be selected to be used as visual cues. However, at night the visibility of these features is reduced or even impossible, making it challenging for the pilots to follow the original flight plan based on daytime visual references. The limited visibility at night might cause difficulty to the pilots in identifying landmarks and reference points to verify the position of the aircraft and cross-check the aircraft track, thus there is a danger of flying into terrain in the case of being lost. Therefore, the difficulty to identify the navigation features at night is the most significant hazard because it directly affects the pilot's ability to navigate safely and accurately during the flight. Tall obstacles at night are properly marked, and can be managed with proper planning, preparation, and adherence to procedures designed for night flying. Note: The difficulty to the pilots in identifying landmarks and reference points is caused due to limited visibility, so the choice 'Limited visibility and off-navigation challenges.' is a hazard but the most significant aspect of limited visibility is the inability to identify the landmarks. This is why the choice 'Difficulty in identifying landmarks and reference points.' is chosen the correct one.

content.question: You are flying a low level VFR flight over a snowy area with no visual checkpoints. What should you do?

options.A: Climb to a higher level and initiate the lost procedure.
options.D: Proceed and turn at the next checkpoint based on time.

key_points: IMPORTANT NOTE: There exist two akin questions within the database
Question 615066 specifies the pilot being lost
In cases where the pilot cannot verify their position, it is advised to initiate the "unsure of position" procedure
learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: There exist two akin questions within the database. Question 615066 specifies the pilot being lost. In cases where the pilot cannot verify their position, it is advised to initiate the "unsure of position" procedure. Should the pilot be unable to ascertain their position even after, they should proceed with the "lost procedure." Nevertheless, if the pilot possesses knowledge of their location, they should proceed according to the original plan. In this case, given that the flight is scheduled to take place over a snowy region lacking ground landmarks, the pilot needs to exercise meticulous care in adhering to the predetermined headings. It's crucial to uphold situational awareness throughout the entire flight duration, consistently assess the flight's progress, and particularly when approaching a designated turning point devoid of visible ground references, make the turn toward the subsequent waypoint according to the pre-calculated time established during the planning phase. Unlike question 615066, this particular question does not indicate that the pilot is disoriented or lost. Consequently, there is no justification for initiating the "lost procedure". content.question: A VFR flight is planned with a chart whose scale is 1:500 000. The ground feature which should be used for orientation is/are:

key_points: “A small hill
” Incorrect
When looking down from the aircraft, the ground appears to flatten
learning.explanation: “A small hill.” Incorrect. When looking down from the aircraft, the ground appears to flatten. For instance, if the pilot selects the first tower as a visual marking, it may be confused with the remaining towers. If the towers have similar features this is probable. “Small roads crossing.” Correct. An intersection of small roads is a good visual marking as it stands out from its surroundings and is visible from a VFR altitude. “A fruit farm.” Incorrect A fruit farm provides low contrast with the surroundings as it may be mistaken with similar field nearby.

Still, remain disciplined and avoid cutting corners
learning.explanation: It is very important that the pilot performs a full preflight for a night flight. The temptation to skip or skim over steps in the preflight is much higher at night when you are juggling a flashlight along with the ladder and fuel cap. Still, remain disciplined and avoid cutting corners. It is also paramount that you familiarize yourself with night flying illusions. Night flying illusions are common and can be deadly if not recognized and compensated for quickly. Learn how to identify and recover from all the tricks your senses can play on you in the dark. The pilot must study the obstacles in the area over which he/she plans to fly, but also the obstacles around the intended route in case, for example, a deviation is necessary. "The airport can not be identified due to lighting." Incorrect - The airport facilities and runways will be lighted, making it possible for the pilot to identify it. "The obstacles marked with red light due to red wavelength." Incorrect – Such lights are used to warn the pilots for the presence of obstacles.

PICKING THE BEST CHECKPOINTS Finding a good VFR checkpoint is a matter of location, size, and distance. Large objects that contrast well with the surrounding environment are the best choice. Ground features on or close to track are preferred. Here's a list of some of the easiest points to spot from the air: Airports with Paved Runways: The taxiways and runways of nearby airports are easy to spot due to large clearings. They also contrast with the grass around them. Railroads: Railroads are relatively easy to spot due to large clearings made for tracks. Highways: Multi-lane highways are easy to spot from the air. Major Road Intersections: Major road and highway intersections with multiple cloverleaf turnoffs are easily spotted. Large Rivers: Looks for rivers that are drawn with some level of open-water width. Small streams are simple lines, while rivers are drawn wider on your sectional chart. Large Lakes with Definable Shapes: If a lake has an easily definable shape, it'll be easy to spot from the air. Towns with Prominent Features: Does the town you're looking for have a major road, railway, or water tower?

content.question: An island appears 30° to the left of the aircraft’s longitudinal axis. What is the true bearing of the aircraft from the island if at the time of observation the aircraft was on a magnetic heading MH of 020° with the magnetic variation VAR 25°W?

key_points: Relative bearing is the clockwise angle from the fore/aft axis of the aircraft to the station
QDR Aircraft’s Magnetic Bearing from the station (Radial); QDM Aircraft’s Magnetic bearing to the station; QTE Aircraft’s True Bearing from the station; QUJ Aircraft’s True Track to the station
NOTE: QDM is the reciprocal of QDR; QUJ is the reciprocal of QTE
learning.explanation: Relative bearing is the clockwise angle from the fore/aft axis of the aircraft to the station. QDR Aircraft’s Magnetic Bearing from the station (Radial); QDM Aircraft’s Magnetic bearing to the station; QTE Aircraft’s True Bearing from the station; QUJ Aircraft’s True Track to the station. NOTE: QDM is the reciprocal of QDR; QUJ is the reciprocal of QTE. Converting a Relative Bearing (RBI) into a True Bearing: Apply aircraft variation to the magnetic heading to get true heading. Add relative bearing to true heading in order to obtain true bearing TO the station If the answer comes to more than 360°(T), subtract 360. Take the reciprocal in order to get the True Bearing to plot FROM the station. QUJ = RBI + True Heading QTE = RBI + True Heading +180º To obtain a True Heading from the Magnetic Heading: True Heading (T) Variation (V) Magnetic Heading (M) Deviation (D) Compass Heading (C) 355º 25ºW 020º The relative bearing is always measured clockwise from the nose of the aircraft, 30º left is the same as RBI 330º. Aircraft’s True Track from the island, QTE = 330º + 355º + 180º = 865º 865º - 2 x 360º = 145º (T)

options.A: It is rectangular and easily confused with surrounding terrain.

key_points: VFR checkpoints are visual references on the ground that pilots use to help navigate during VFR flights
These checkpoints are selected based on certain characteristics to ensure they are easily recognizable and can be reliably identified from the air

When choosing VFR checkpoints, the following should be taken into account: Size and Distinctiveness: Favorable checkpoints exhibit considerable size, since they must be identified even when observed from a considerable distance or altitude
learning.explanation: VFR checkpoints are visual references on the ground that pilots use to help navigate during VFR flights. These checkpoints are selected based on certain characteristics to ensure they are easily recognizable and can be reliably identified from the air. When choosing VFR checkpoints, the following should be taken into account: Size and Distinctiveness: Favorable checkpoints exhibit considerable size, since they must be identified even when observed from a considerable distance or altitude. They should have unique features that differentiate them from other nearby object. Prominence: Checkpoints should stand out from their surroundings. They could be easily recognizable structures, geographical features, or landmarks that can be seen from a distance. Contrast with Terrain: Checkpoints should exhibit visual contrast with the surrounding terrain. This contrast can result from differences in color, texture, shape, or elevation. Proximity to Intended Path: Optimal VFR checkpoints lie directly on or in close proximity to the planned flight track, enhancing navigation accuracy. Planned Altitude Consideration: When selecting checkpoints, the intended cruising altitude must be considered. Lower altitudes might obscure a chosen reference point due to elevated terrain, or it might only become visible once the aircraft has traversed over it for a limited duration. A tall rectangular building is a suitable ground feature for VFR navigation, because it is has the following characteristics: It has enough vertical extent to be identified from a considerable distance and altitude, and it has a distinctive shape that makes it easily recognizable. It is prominent and unique, standing out against the surrounding terrain. It makes contrast with its surroundings due to differences in shape and elevation.

For Relative Bearing: 280º True Bearing from the aircraft to the feature = True heading + Relative Bearing True Bearing from the aircraft to the feature = 140º + 280º = 060º True Bearing of the aircraft from the feature = 060º + 180º = 240º (Position B) For Relative Bearing: 325º True Bearing from the aircraft to the feature = True heading + Relative Bearing True Bearing from the aircraft to the feature = 140º + 325º = 465º - 360º = 105º True Bearing of the aircraft from the feature = 105º + 180º = 285º (Position A) Note that the aircraft flies from position A to position B. True Track = True Heading + Right Drift True Track = 140º + 010º = 150º The above calculation will be important for the drawing. => CONCLUSION: When the relative bearing is 280º (Position B), the true bearing of the aircraft from the feature equals 240º and the distance from B to the feature equals 30 NM.

key_points: Some of the problems faced by a pilot during VFR navigation at lower levels are the following: The horizon may be obscured by high ground, so attitude flying is difficult
Frequent changes may be needed to maintain the correct airspeed, while climbing or descending over undulating ground
The view ahead and around is restricted by the next fold of high ground
learning.explanation: Some of the problems faced by a pilot during VFR navigation at lower levels are the following: The horizon may be obscured by high ground, so attitude flying is difficult. Frequent changes may be needed to maintain the correct airspeed, while climbing or descending over undulating ground. The view ahead and around is restricted by the next fold of high ground. The angle at which you are looking becomes flatter and if a feature does not have some vertical extent, you are unlikely to see it at low level. A selected visual check point may be hidden by high ground or only visible after the aircraft has passed over it and for a limited period of time. Thus, it will be difficult to fly past them. As for the question's options: Features with great vertical extent can be easily seen. The pilot feels that flies at a higher groundspeed. content.question: Identifying landmarks and overall orientation and visualisation of the inflight situation on a VFR flight can be made easy by:

options.A: Holding the complete map with North-up orientation.
options.B: Holding the complete map with track-up orientation.
options.C: Holding a relevant part of the map with track-up orientation.
options.D: Holding only a small part of the map with North-up orientation.

key_points: In VFR flights, the aeronautical chart consists the basis of VFR navigation

One of the most common methods to navigate under VFR is by selecting, during the pre-flight planning procedure, the ground features, which are marked on the VFR chart and then seeking for them on the ground during the flight

The VFR charts depict topographic features and other information of interest to pilots flying visually, such as major landmarks, terrain elevations, visual navigation routes, ground-based navigation aids, airports, rivers, cities, airspace boundaries, etc
learning.explanation: In VFR flights, the aeronautical chart consists the basis of VFR navigation. One of the most common methods to navigate under VFR is by selecting, during the pre-flight planning procedure, the ground features, which are marked on the VFR chart and then seeking for them on the ground during the flight. The VFR charts depict topographic features and other information of interest to pilots flying visually, such as major landmarks, terrain elevations, visual navigation routes, ground-based navigation aids, airports, rivers, cities, airspace boundaries, etc. During VFR navigation, the cadets are usually instructed to hold the map oriented to the direction of flight, so that the surrounding topographic features can be easily identified, i.e. hold the map so that direction of flight is at the top (not North), also known as "track-up", so "right" on the map will correspond to "right" on the ground and map reading will be easier. Using the chart “track-up”, gives the best situational awareness to the crew and it can also be useful to check if the aircraft is on the planned position by checking if the ground features coincide with your expectations. Also, for convenience during flight, it is not necessary to hold the whole navigation chart, but it is preferred to hold only a a relevant with the trip part of the whole chart, so as not to reduce the pilot's field of view and handling effectiveness. "North-up" map orientation is mainly suggested for flight planning.

content.question: Which one of the following situations mostly increases the risk of Controlled Flight Into Terrain (CFIT) during a VFR flight?

options.D: Flying overwater with a strong surface wind.

key_points: Controlled Flight into Terrain (CFIT) is defined as an unintentional collision with terrain, while an aircraft is under positive control
CFIT occurs when an airworthy aircraft under the complete control of the pilot is inadvertently flown into terrain, water, or an obstacle
The pilots are generally unaware of the danger until it is too late
learning.explanation: Controlled Flight into Terrain (CFIT) is defined as an unintentional collision with terrain, while an aircraft is under positive control. CFIT occurs when an airworthy aircraft under the complete control of the pilot is inadvertently flown into terrain, water, or an obstacle. The pilots are generally unaware of the danger until it is too late. Many CFIT accidents occur because of loss of situational awareness and may happen not only in night or IMC conditions, but even in a VFR flight during the day. Accidents where the aircraft is out of control at the point of impact are not known as CFIT. Rather, they are considered uncontrolled flight into terrain. Similarly, incidents resulting from deliberate acts, such as terrorism or suicide by the pilot, are also not considered to be CFIT. Overcast sky and Snow-Covered Terrain - CORRECT: This is a situation where the snow-covered terrain and the overcast sky are mixed making the horizon invisible. The lack of the poor colour contrast, ground features and shadows increase the likelihood of loss of situational awareness by the pilot, creating illusions of climbing or descending while he/she actually flies level.

content.question: On a VFR navigation flight, which of the following visual checkpoints is suitable to determine the aircraft’s ground speed regarding the calculated time ticks?

options.A: An 800 ft radio mast on the horizon.
options.B: A railroad perpendicular to the track.
options.C: A straight highway along the calculated track.
options.D: A large waterway in the direction of the aircraft’s nose.

key_points: "An 400 ft radio mast on the horizon
" INCORRECT
Identifying features with significant vertical extent, such as masts and mountains, is crucial for safety during flight
learning.explanation: "An 400 ft radio mast on the horizon." INCORRECT. Identifying features with significant vertical extent, such as masts and mountains, is crucial for safety during flight. However, they also serve as excellent visual checkpoints due to their visibility from a distance, especially in favorable weather conditions. These features become valuable references for navigation purposes. However, It's essential to recognize that the usefulness of features with substantial vertical extent may decrease as you fly at higher altitudes. When flying at 5,000 feet above ground level (AGL), a 400-foot-high mast might become difficult to spot due to its diminished visual prominence. "A railroad perpendicular to the track." CORRECT. This is a conspicuous landmark with a great extent which can be easily located and identified from the altitude at which a VFR flight is normally operating. since this road is crossing perpendicularly the planned track, the crossing point could be used to check for any time deviation and to calculate the actual ground speed. "A straight highway along the calculated track." INCORRECT. A landmark, even if easily identifiable, is not useful to check the aircraft's groundspeed as it wil not be crossing the path at any point. When flying, because of the great extent along the track, a second conspicuous landmark close to the crossing point is required. "A large waterway in the direction of the aircraft’s nose." INCORRECT. While a large waterway can be a visual reference point and used as a checkpoint, it may not be as accurate or easy to measure ground speed as a perpendicular railroad track. Determining ground speed using a waterway may involve more challenges including, in this case, lack of perpendicular reference: Unlike a railroad track, which runs perpendicular to your flight path, a waterway may or may not be at a right angle to your track. Measuring the time it takes to fly over a distance along the waterway may not directly correspond to your ground speed due to the angle between your flight path and the waterway.

An island is observed to be 30° to the right of the aircraft’s longitudinal axis.The aircraft heading is 290°M, variation 10°E.
The bearing from the aircraft to the island is…

key_points: Relative bearing is the clockwise angle from the fore/aft axis of the aircraft to the station
QDR Aircraft’s Magnetic Bearing from the station (Radial); QDM Aircraft’s Magnetic bearing to the station; QTE Aircraft’s True Bearing from the station; QUJ Aircraft’s True Track to the station
NOTE: QDM is the reciprocal of QDR; QUJ is the reciprocal of QTE
learning.explanation: Relative bearing is the clockwise angle from the fore/aft axis of the aircraft to the station. NOTE: QDM is the reciprocal of QDR; QUJ is the reciprocal of QTE. Converting a Relative Bearing (RBI) into a True Bearing: Apply aircraft variation to the magnetic heading to get true heading. Add relative bearing to true heading in order to obtain true bearing TO the station If the answer comes to more than 360°(T), subtract 360. Take the reciprocal in order to get the True Bearing to plot FROM the station. QUJ = RBI + True Heading QTE = RBI + True Heading +180º To obtain a True Heading from the Magnetic Heading: True Heading (T) Variation (V) Magnetic Heading (M) Deviation (D) Compass Heading (C) 300º 10ºE 290º The relative bearing is always measured clockwise from the nose of the aircraft, 30º right is the same as RBI 030º. Aircraft’s True Track to the island, QUJ = 030º + 300º = 330º (T)

key_points: Controlled Flight into Terrain (CFIT) is defined as an unintentional collision with terrain (the ground, a mountain, a body of water, or an obstacle) while an aircraft is under positive control
Most often, the pilot or crew is unaware of the looming disaster until it is too late
Accidents where the aircraft is out of control at the point of impact are not known as CFIT
learning.explanation: Controlled Flight into Terrain (CFIT) is defined as an unintentional collision with terrain (the ground, a mountain, a body of water, or an obstacle) while an aircraft is under positive control. Most often, the pilot or crew is unaware of the looming disaster until it is too late. Accidents where the aircraft is out of control at the point of impact are not known as CFIT. Rather, they are considered uncontrolled flight into terrain. Similarly, incidents resulting from deliberate acts, such as terrorism or suicide by the pilot, are also not considered to be CFIT. One major factor of CFIT is the loss of situational awareness — failing to know at all times what the aircraft’s position is, how that position relates to the altitude of the surface immediately below and ahead, and how both relate to the course being flown. One of the contributory factors is weather: Rain, turbulence, clouds and icing, may increase the workload of the pilot and cause interference reducing the accuracy of radio navigation beacons. Poor visibility, particularly at night can contribute to disorientation and loss of situational awareness.

learning.explanation: Checkpoints are prominent buildings or landmarks that can be visually easy to identify from the air. PICKING THE BEST CHECKPOINTS Finding a good VFR checkpoint is a matter of location, size, and distance. Large objects that contrast well with the surrounding environment are the best choice. Ground features on or close to track are preferred. Here's a list of some of the easiest points to spot from the air: Airports with Paved Runways: The taxiways and runways of nearby airports are easy to spot due to large clearings. They also contrast with the grass around them. Railroads: Railroads are relatively easy to spot due to large clearings made for tracks. Highways: Multi-lane highways are easy to spot from the air. Major Road Intersections: Major road and highway intersections with multiple cloverleaf turnoffs are easily spotted. Large Rivers: Looks for rivers that are drawn with some level of open-water width. Small streams are simple lines, while rivers are drawn wider on your sectional chart. Large Lakes with Definable Shapes: If a lake has an easily definable shape, it'll be easy to spot from the air. Towns with Prominent Features: Does the town you're looking for have a major road, railway, or water tower? With regards to this question, large water reservoir, tall masts and a high tension power line are good checkpoints. Areas with small woods and streets in a town are not unique. A fruit farm provides low contrast with the surroundings as it may be mistaken with similar field nearby.

Calculate the Track Error Angle if the aircraft is 1.5 NM left of track after 12 minutes of flying.

key_points: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning
If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track
The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good
learning.explanation: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning. If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track. The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good. The difference between them is called track error (TE). The angle at which we want to close to come back to the planned track is the closing angle (CA). The CA will depend how much further we want to rejoin the planned track. The 1 in 60 rule can be used to calculate the TE: TE = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 Planned track distance flown = 180 x 12’ = 36 NM TE = (1.5/36) x 60 = 2.5º L

Planned Altitude Consideration: When selecting checkpoints, the intended cruising altitude must be considered. Lower altitudes might obscure a chosen reference point due to elevated terrain, or it might only become visible once the aircraft has traversed over it for a limited duration. The selected feature has a white colour. On a winter day, during a special VFR flight with low clouds, reduced visibility, and a snowy surface, the feature will have the same colour with the ground and the surrounding features. This means that it will not make any visual contrast with the surrounding terrain and the pilot will find it extremely difficult to recognize it.

They also contrast with the grass around them. Railroads: Railroads are relatively easy to spot due to large clearings made for tracks. Highways: Multi-lane highways are easy to spot from the air. Major Road Intersections: Major road and highway intersections with multiple cloverleaf turnoffs are easily spotted. Large Rivers: Looks for rivers that are drawn with some level of open-water width. Small streams are simple lines, while rivers are drawn wider on your sectional chart. Large Lakes with Definable Shapes: If a lake has an easily definable shape, it'll be easy to spot from the air. Towns with Prominent Features: Does the town you're looking for have a major road, railway, or water tower?

content.question: The pilot is in radio contact with an Air Traffic Control unit but has become unsure of the aircraft's position. The pilot's initial action(s) if fuel is NOT critical is:

options.A: Continue to fly on the current heading until position is established.
options.B: Change frequency to 121.5 MHz and make an urgency (PAN) call.
options.C: Turn back towards the aircraft's last confirmed position.
options.D: Note the time and request assistance from the ATC unit.

5 MHz and make a PAN call; If that is not necessary, check the directional indicator (DI) and compass are still synchronised and continue to fly straight and level and on route plan heading; Estimate the distance travelled since the last known position; Compare the ground with your estimated position on the map (look at the terrain for hills and valleys or line features such as a motorway, railway, river or coastline; Once the position has been re-established, keep checking the heading (and look out for other aircraft) and continue the flight by updating the estimated position regularly while looking for unique features such as a lake, wood, built-up area, mast or a combination of roads, rivers and railways

They can indicate gradient as well as height

content.question: What is the danger about power lines when flying VFR over a snowy area?

options.A: Always marked on the map, no problem.
options.B: Due to their small vertical extents, not a factor.
options.C: Represent a danger when flying over a mountain's ridge.
options.D: Represent a danger when power lines cross a valley.

key_points: For this question examine each statement carefully: "Always marked on the map, no problem
" - Incorrect: Usually only the high voltage power lines are depicted on a chart, but not always

The pilot flying VFR must be very careful with the power lines, especially during take-off or landing, where the required altitude which provides obstacle clearance has not been reached yet or the aircraft is quite below the minimum safe altitude correspongingly
learning.explanation: For this question examine each statement carefully: "Always marked on the map, no problem." - Incorrect: Usually only the high voltage power lines are depicted on a chart, but not always. The pilot flying VFR must be very careful with the power lines, especially during take-off or landing, where the required altitude which provides obstacle clearance has not been reached yet or the aircraft is quite below the minimum safe altitude correspongingly. "Due to their small vertical extents, not a factor." - Incorrect: The low voltage power lines have indeed a small vertical extent, but the high voltage ones have a greater one, posing the flight at risk when flying at low altitude. "Represent a danger when flying over a mountain's ridge." - Incorrect: When flying over snow covered mountain ridges in overcast low cloud ceiling conditions, the poor contrast makes it difficult for the pilot to distinguish the sky from the ground and a false perception of the distance, depth and altitude is created with an invisible horizon. But, the power lines are rarely installed over mountain ridges and if installed their height is quite low. "Represent a danger when power lines cross a valley." - CORRECT: In most cases the power lines cross valleys rather than ridges. Over a snowy area, the high voltage power lines can be easily distinguished, but not the low voltage ones due to their smaller vertical extent.

content.question:
A pilot planning a VFR flight leg is looking for a ground feature part-way a long a leg that is NOT in built up area. All of the following are depicted on the VFR chart in suitable locations for a visual fix. Which might allow the pilot to check for any drifting error along the track?
1. Dual-carriageway (four line) road crossing the intended track.
2. Dual-carriageway (four line) road crossing a river close to the intended track.
3. Disused railway crossing a river on intended track.
4. Single carriageway (two line) road crossing a railway close to intended track.

key_points: To check for drifting errors along the intended track during VFR flight, it's essential to identify conspicuous landmarks close to the track
These landmarks should be easily locatable and distinguishable from the VFR flight altitude
Using these landmarks, pilots can monitor flight progress and calculate ground speed
learning.explanation: To check for drifting errors along the intended track during VFR flight, it's essential to identify conspicuous landmarks close to the track. These landmarks should be easily locatable and distinguishable from the VFR flight altitude. Using these landmarks, pilots can monitor flight progress and calculate ground speed. "1. Dual-carriageway (four line) road crossing the intended track." INCORRECT. This is a prominent landmark, yet its vast expanse presents challenges for pilots in accurately identifying the precise crossing point from the air. As a result, it is advisable not to rely solely on this landmark for drift error checks. "2. Dual-carriageway (four line) road crossing a river close to the intended track." CORRECT. This prominent landmark lies in close proximity to the intended flight track, distinguished by its substantial size and stark contrast against the surroundings. During the planning stage, pilots can use its position as a reference point relative to the track. While in-flight, comparing the aircraft's position with this easily identifiable landmark on the chart enables the assessment of any potential drift error. "3. Disused railway crossing a river on intended track." CORRECT. Even though the railway line is disused, the point where this railway line crosses the river can be easily located due to the color contrast with the surroundings. "Single carriageway (two line) road crossing a railway close to intended track." CORRECT. Similar to a Dual-carriageway (four-line) road, this conspicuous landmark lies in close proximity to the intended flight track and can be easily located and identified from the altitude of a VFR (Visual Flight Rules) flight. By cross-referencing the aircraft's position relative to this landmark during the flight, the pilot can pinpoint their location on the chart and assess for any potential drift error.

content.question:
When navigating from chart to ground, what are the best navigation features to use?
1. Large water features
2. Farmland
3. Tall obstacles
4. Isolated towns
5. Power lines

key_points: NOTE: There is another question in the database that is similar to this question (615463) and asks for the best VFR features, but it has different options
We have seen many different feedback for these questions and we believe there are several versions used by EASA

So far the ‘rule’ for these questions is that ‘farmland’ is never correct and if high-tension power lines are present, they are correct (this is a debatable point, but sometimes a good VFR feature, particularly in forested areas)
learning.explanation: NOTE: There is another question in the database that is similar to this question (615463) and asks for the best VFR features, but it has different options. We have seen many different feedback for these questions and we believe there are several versions used by EASA. So far the ‘rule’ for these questions is that ‘farmland’ is never correct and if high-tension power lines are present, they are correct (this is a debatable point, but sometimes a good VFR feature, particularly in forested areas). After that, it is common sense. Checkpoints are prominent buildings or landmarks that can be visually easy to identify from the air. PICKING THE BEST CHECKPOINTS Finding a good VFR checkpoint is a matter of location, size, and distance. Large objects that contrast well with the surrounding environment are the best choice. Ground features on or close to track are preferred. Here's a list of some of the easiest points to spot from the air: Airports with Paved Runways: The taxiways and runways of nearby airports are easy to spot due to large clearings. They also contrast with the grass around them. Railroads: Railroads are relatively easy to spot due to large clearings made for tracks. Highways: Multi-lane highways are easy to spot from the air. Major Road Intersections: Major road and highway intersections with multiple cloverleaf turnoffs are easily spotted. Large Rivers: Looks for rivers that are drawn with some level of open-water width. Small streams are simple lines, while rivers are drawn wider on your sectional chart. Large Lakes with Definable Shapes: If a lake has an easily definable shape, it'll be easy to spot from the air. Towns with Prominent Features: Does the town you're looking for have a major road, railway, or water tower? Tall Towers or Masts: Easy to see at low level and always marked on charts due to their height, they can be excellent features for VFR navigation, as long as they aren't tall enough to hit. Power lines aren't always good as some have thin wires that don't stand out very well, but they are large features and cause large clearings to be made, which are easy to spot, particularly in a forest. Telephone lines, on the other hand, are much smaller and VERY difficult to see from high up. And, a farmland provides low contrast with the surroundings as it may be mistaken with similar field nearby.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
You are about to take a VFR flight in Summer with no serviceable radio aids on board your aircraft. The flight is likely to occur in haze in the late afternoon, with the Sun deteriorating visibility even more. Which route should you plan to take?

options.B: Route 2 via the highway then the river.
options.D: Route 4 via the big city of Regensburg.

key_points: VFR navigation is highly affected by the choice of route, and particularly features to use for turning points or tracking

In this case, with quite poor visibility, due to the haze and the Sun to the West, the best way to navigate given here is to use the large line features of the highway and the river, which can be followed all the way to the destination
It does not add too much distance to the route, but does make sure that the pilot will always know their position and will not become lost or disorientated
learning.explanation: VFR navigation is highly affected by the choice of route, and particularly features to use for turning points or tracking. In this case, with quite poor visibility, due to the haze and the Sun to the West, the best way to navigate given here is to use the large line features of the highway and the river, which can be followed all the way to the destination. It does not add too much distance to the route, but does make sure that the pilot will always know their position and will not become lost or disorientated. The VOR cannot be used for navigation due to the lack of serviceable equipment on the aircraft. The tall mast may be an acceptable turning point, but might be difficult to identify in the Sun and the haze, and the long legs with reduced visibility could lead the aircraft to being off course and have a higher chance of getting the pilot lost than following the highway and river. The 4th route is not even on the map, and is similar to using the mast, though it is much likely easier to find, but is large and therefore less accurate as a position fix.

options.A: Inability to identify visual references, placed near mountain ridges.
options.D: Visual references will be visible for a limited period of time.

key_points: When planning a route, the pilot will use visual check points to monitor the flight progress along a flight leg
Choice of the ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps, do not necessarily show up well from the air
Thus, the pilot should consider: Proximity to planned track: Ground features on or close to the track are preferred
learning.explanation: When planning a route, the pilot will use visual check points to monitor the flight progress along a flight leg. Choice of the ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps, do not necessarily show up well from the air. Thus, the pilot should consider: Proximity to planned track: Ground features on or close to the track are preferred. Size and uniqueness: Large objects with colour contrast and/or some vertical extent will be easier to identify. Time of the year: Changes in vegetation or snow cover can cause the same landscape to take on a different appearance at different times of the year. Planned Altitude: At lower levels, a selected visual check point may be hidden by high ground or only visible after the aircraft has passed over it and for a limited period of time.

Thereafter distance flown in 3 minutes (9 NM) equal distance from airplane new location to NDB = 9 NM Correct Answer: 9 NM

Refer to figure.
A pilot is performing a VFR flight just under the low cloud base following the route above, and at Fruges Windfarm, they get cleared to fly directly to DET VOR/DME. While flying directly towards DET VOR/DME, they realise at 15:00 that the on-board GPS equipment has been showing unreliable indications for a few minutes and the pilot becomes unsure of their position. Which of the following should the pilot do in this case?
1. Tune in to the DET VOR/DME frequency if within radio range, find their position and pass it to the ATC asking for assistance.
2. Climb to a higher level to increase radio range.
3. Follow the calculated heading towards DET VOR/DME.
4. Follow the flight legs according to the operational flight plan.
5. Orbit and look for the M20 Junction.

key_points: Note: We have received some varying feedback for this question and the statements involved

We think that this question is the most representative of the current feedback, but please do let us know if you see any similar question in the real exam, and anything you remember about it, thank you There are some generic ways to deal with position uncertainty listed below, but in this case, the pilot should tune DET VOR/DME and fly straight towards it, using a previously calculated direction if no signal is received
As they are no longer on their flight planned route, following the OFP is not very useful, and the low cloud means they cannot climb higher whilst remaining VMC
learning.explanation: Note: We have received some varying feedback for this question and the statements involved. We think that this question is the most representative of the current feedback, but please do let us know if you see any similar question in the real exam, and anything you remember about it, thank you There are some generic ways to deal with position uncertainty listed below, but in this case, the pilot should tune DET VOR/DME and fly straight towards it, using a previously calculated direction if no signal is received. As they are no longer on their flight planned route, following the OFP is not very useful, and the low cloud means they cannot climb higher whilst remaining VMC. When a pilot becomes in doubt about their position, they should perform some or all of the following actions: 1. Note the time. 2. Communicate, if in contact with an Air Traffic Control (ATC) unit, to request assistance. 3. Consider using any radio-navigation aids that may be available to give position information. 4. If short of fuel or near controlled airspace and not in contact with ATC, set 121.5 MHz and make a PAN call. 5. If that is not necessary, check the directional indicator (DI) and compass are still synchronised and continue to fly straight and level and on the planned heading. 6. Estimate the distance travelled since the last known position. 7. Compare the ground with the aircraft's estimated position on the map. When the aircraft’s position is uncertain, ground features must be turned into a mentally perceived picture of the map and related to the map symbols. Line features such as coastlines, railways, large highways, etc. can be easy to find and useful to then fly along until you can find your position on the map. 8. Once the position has been re-established, keep checking the heading and continue the flight by updating the estimated position regularly while looking for unique features such as hills, valleys, lakes, wood, built-up areas, rivers, coastlines, motorways and railways. In any case, maintain VMC and visual contact with the ground, note the fuel state and, if necessary, try to identify an area suitable for a precautionary landing.

content.question:
An island appears 30° to the right of the aircraft’s longitudinal axis.
What is the true bearing of the aircraft from the island if at the time of observation the aircraft was on a magnetic heading MH of 355° with the magnetic variation VAR 15°E?

key_points: Relative bearing is the clockwise angle from the fore/aft axis of the aircraft to the station
QDR Aircraft’s Magnetic Bearing from the station (Radial); QDM Aircraft’s Magnetic bearing to the station; QTE Aircraft’s True Bearing from the station; QUJ Aircraft’s True Track to the station
NOTE: QDM is the reciprocal of QDR; QUJ is the reciprocal of QTE
learning.explanation: Relative bearing is the clockwise angle from the fore/aft axis of the aircraft to the station. QDR Aircraft’s Magnetic Bearing from the station (Radial); QDM Aircraft’s Magnetic bearing to the station; QTE Aircraft’s True Bearing from the station; QUJ Aircraft’s True Track to the station. NOTE: QDM is the reciprocal of QDR; QUJ is the reciprocal of QTE. Converting a Relative Bearing (RBI) into a True Bearing: Apply aircraft variation to the magnetic heading to get true heading. Add relative bearing to true heading in order to obtain true bearing TO the station If the answer comes to more than 360°(T), subtract 360. Take the reciprocal in order to get the True Bearing to plot FROM the station. QUJ = RBI + True Heading QTE = RBI + True Heading +180º To obtain a True Heading from the Magnetic Heading: True Heading (T) Variation (V) Magnetic Heading (M) Deviation (D) Compass Heading (C) 010º 15ºE 355º The relative bearing is always measured clockwise from the nose of the aircraft, 30º right is the same as RBI 030º. Aircraft’s True Track from the island, QTE = 030º + 010º +180º = 220º (T)

content.question: Which one of the following below may reduce the visibility for an aircraft performing a low level VFR flight on a day with clear sky?

options.B: Flying downwind of factories producing smoke.
options.C: Flying with the sun behind the aircraft.
options.D: Sun is high in the sky.

key_points: The pilots flying VFR must check if the sky is obscured, meaning that something is totally or partially blocking his/her view of either the sky or the ground
Obscurations (and their abbreviations) include: mist (BR), fog (FG), smoke (FU), volcanic ash (VA), sand (SA), haze (HZ), spray (PY), and widespread dust (DU)
Smoke may come from factories and forest fires
learning.explanation: The pilots flying VFR must check if the sky is obscured, meaning that something is totally or partially blocking his/her view of either the sky or the ground. Obscurations (and their abbreviations) include: mist (BR), fog (FG), smoke (FU), volcanic ash (VA), sand (SA), haze (HZ), spray (PY), and widespread dust (DU). Smoke may come from factories and forest fires. Even far downwind of smoke, the smoke is often spread out, somewhat uniformly, within the bottom several low levels of the atmosphere. In some cases the smoke is so thick that it is difficult to see the bottom parts of the clouds and can reduce visibility to the point, where it is a hazard to aviation. Furthermore, visibility may be also reduced, if flying with the sun in front of the aircraft or with the Sun low in the sky.

content.question: During visual navigation in freezing conditions, after heavy snowfall, which of the following landmark will give the best reference for a visual checkpoint:

key_points: Unless you’re flying quite low, power lines may be another tricky ground feature
A good way to spot and follow them is to find the power line pylons
They’re more visible than the power line itself, so easier to identify
learning.explanation: Unless you’re flying quite low, power lines may be another tricky ground feature. A good way to spot and follow them is to find the power line pylons. They’re more visible than the power line itself, so easier to identify. Being a high obstacle over the ground in icing conditions and over an area covered by snow the high pylons will stand out cause the snow will not stack over the power line pylons. The same for high antennas which are identified on the VFR charts. The question should be clearer because it depends on the time of the year, on the conditions (if there was some snow and/or cold temperatures before, and for how long) and EASA should also mention the location. Depending on conditions and location, rivers can freeze. Several students confirmed that "high-tension lines" was correct in their official examination and that the answers given were "high-tension lines" (instead of "electrical line") and "river" (instead of large river), so we changed the question and correct answer in 2 016-06. The correct answer before was "a large river". If this question appears differently in your official examination, please let us know.

content.question: What is the best visual reporting point for an aircraft flying a VFR flight above a hilly area?

options.B: Few small rivers that leave a big river.

key_points: Visual reporting points are prominent buildings or landmarks that can be visually easy to identify from the air
The choice of ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps do not necessarily show up well from the air
So, among others, you should also consider the uniqueness and the contrast of the ground features
learning.explanation: Visual reporting points are prominent buildings or landmarks that can be visually easy to identify from the air. The choice of ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps do not necessarily show up well from the air. So, among others, you should also consider the uniqueness and the contrast of the ground features. After examining the options given below the answer, we come to the following conclusions: The contrast of an object to its background has a notable effect on its visibility. If contrast is high (for example a valley against a hilly area), then the range at which objects can be seen is increased. A hill or a slightly steeper hillside within a hilly area does not provide uniqueness. Also, few small rivers that leave a big river may provide contrast, regarding the colours against the surrounding environment, but they are not unique. The big river at its own could be a preferable ground feature as a visual reporting point contrary to the few small rivers. Therefore, the best visual reporting point for an aircraft flying a VFR flight above a hilly area, seems to be a valley.

content.question: An aircraft is making a VFR flight under freezing conditions after recent heavy snow fall. Which of the following land marks will provide the most reliable reference?

options.B: A railway track (without an overhead line).

key_points: "A railway track (without an overhead line)
" and "A country road
" Incorrect
learning.explanation: "A railway track (without an overhead line)." and "A country road." Incorrect. Question states recent heavy snow fall. In such conditions, country roads and railways would most likely be covered in snow and very hard to spot. "A river." Incorrect. Depending on the conditions and location, rivers can freeze (especially small rivers). This would make it difficult to spot them, they would blend in with the surroundings (snow covered fields). "A high-tension power line (with towers)." Correct. Snow would not fully cover a high tension power line. Additionally, most high tension power lines have Brightly Colored Balls (visibility marker balls) => these will help make power lines more obvious to low-flying aircraft like planes and helicopters.

content.question: An aircraft is flying a low-level VFR route over a mountainous area, which is covered by snow, in high latitudes. Power lines are...

options.A: Dangerous, especially if they cross valleys, but pose less of a risk if they are situated along ridge.
options.B: Dangerous if they are situated along a ridge, but pose less of a risk of they are crossing a valley.
options.C: Easily identified, as they are always marked on maps and can therefore be safely avoided.
options.D: Safely overflown due to their small vertical extent.

key_points: Power lines can be difficult to see, especially in areas with low visibility due to weather conditions, such as snow or fog
When flying over a mountainous area, power lines can pose a significant hazard to low-level flights, particularly if they cross valleys
In such cases, the pilot may not be able to see the power lines until it's too late to take evasive action
learning.explanation: Power lines can be difficult to see, especially in areas with low visibility due to weather conditions, such as snow or fog. When flying over a mountainous area, power lines can pose a significant hazard to low-level flights, particularly if they cross valleys. In such cases, the pilot may not be able to see the power lines until it's too late to take evasive action. Power lines situated along a ridge may be easier to see, but they still pose a risk, especially if the aircraft is flying close to the ridge. It's important for pilots flying low-level VFR routes to exercise caution and remain vigilant for power lines. Maps and charts can help identify potential hazards, but they may not always be up-to-date or accurate. In addition, some power lines may not be marked on charts, so pilots should always be on the lookout for any obstacles that may pose a risk to their flight. The small vertical extent of power lines is not a guarantee of safety, and pilots should always maintain a safe altitude and distance from any potential hazards.

content.question: Which features are the most suitable when flying a VFR flight at low level during the daylight, using checkpoints on a 1:500 000 map?

options.A: Ones that are tall and prominent, such as towers.
options.B: Small ones, such as individual houses distributed over an area of farmland.
options.C: Very large ones, such as an extensive wooded area.
options.D: Minor roads in a built up area.

key_points: When planning a route, the pilot will use visual check points to monitor the flight progress along a flight leg
Choice of the ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps, do not necessarily show up well from the air
Thus, the pilot should consider: Proximity to planned track: Ground features on or close to the track are preferred
learning.explanation: When planning a route, the pilot will use visual check points to monitor the flight progress along a flight leg. Choice of the ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps, do not necessarily show up well from the air. Thus, the pilot should consider: Proximity to planned track: Ground features on or close to the track are preferred. Size and uniqueness: Large objects with colour contrast and/or some vertical extent will be easier to identify. Time of the year: Changes in vegetation or snow cover can cause the same landscape to take on a different appearance at different times of the year. Planned Altitude: At lower levels, a selected visual check point may be hidden by high ground or only visible after the aircraft has passed over it and for a limited period of time. Towers are the most suitable ground features for VFR navigation, if they are unique, since they are tall and prominent with enough vertical extent and can be easily identified from the air. A chart of 1: 500 000 scale is considered as a well enough detailed aeronautical chart, but not so much that small buildings, like individual houses or minor roads can be depicted. Extensive wooden areas cover a very large area, thus cannot be considered as checkpoints and their appearance changes throughout the year.

content.question: On a VFR flight during night, which one of the following has to be considered by a pilot most carefully?

options.A: The trajectory of other aircraft will not be clear, unless their landing lights are illuminated.
options.B: Use of red lights in the cockpit can cause temporary blindness for pilots.
options.C: When looking outside at lit objects, it can cause disorientation with respect to the instrument readings.
options.D: Terrain and obstacles along an approach may not be clearly visible.

key_points: "The trajectory of other aircraft will not be clear, unless their landing lights are illuminated
" - Incorrect

Between sunset and sunrise, all aircraft in flight shall display anti-collision lights to attract attention, navigation lights to indicate the relative path of the aircraft to an observer and landing lights may be used in addition to the anti-collision lights to enhance aircraft cospicuity
learning.explanation: "The trajectory of other aircraft will not be clear, unless their landing lights are illuminated." - Incorrect. Between sunset and sunrise, all aircraft in flight shall display anti-collision lights to attract attention, navigation lights to indicate the relative path of the aircraft to an observer and landing lights may be used in addition to the anti-collision lights to enhance aircraft cospicuity. "Use of red lights in the cockpit can cause temporary blindness for pilots." - Incorrect. The cockpit lighting must be adjusted to improve the night vision and reduce reflections. Cockpit lighting at night is sometimes a red light, because it will affect the rods used for night vision, less than the white light. "When looking outside at lit objects, it can cause disorientation with respect to the instrument readings." - Incorrect. When starring at a single point of light against a dark background, it can appear to move on its own. Disorientation is likely when there are fewer visual cues and references, such as horizon and other line features. "Terrain and obstacles along an approach may not be clearly visible." - Correct. Even though there is unlimited visibility during night and not a cloud in the sky, obstacles and terrain may not be that easy to see.

content.question: Which is the best visual ground feature to establish a checkpoint for a day VFR flight over a mountainous area for an aircraft A flying at 1 000 ft AGL and an aircraft B flying at 5 000 ft AGL?

options.A: High mast for A and big lake for B.
options.B: Big lake for A and high mast for B.
options.C: High mast for both A and B.
options.D: Big lake for both A and B.

learning.explanation: Let's start by determining the distance flown in 3 min (Distance1): Distance1 = 120 x 3 / 60 = 6 NM We know that the Relative bearing at first position is 45˚ to the left. Therefore, triangle angle at airplane location at old position equals 45˚. After three minutes, the Relative bearing is 90˚ to the left. Therefore, after three minutes, the angle in the triangle at airplane location equals 90˚. Difference in bearings = 45˚ Therefore, triangle angle at NDB location = 45˚ As we have triangle with 2 angles of 45˚, it is an isosceles triangle. Therefore, distance flown in 3 minutes (6 NM) equals distance from airplane new location to NDB = 6 NM

Add relative bearing to true heading in order to obtain true bearing TO the station If the answer comes to more than 360°(T), subtract 360. learning.explanation: VFR checkpoints are visual references on the ground that pilots use to help navigate during VFR flights. These checkpoints are selected based on certain characteristics to ensure they are easily recognizable and can be reliably identified from the air. When choosing VFR checkpoints, the following should be taken into account: Size and Distinctiveness: Favorable checkpoints exhibit considerable size, since they must be identified even when observed from a considerable distance or altitude. They should have unique features that differentiate them from other nearby object. Prominence: Checkpoints should stand out from their surroundings. They could be easily recognizable structures, geographical features, or landmarks that can be seen from a distance. Contrast with Terrain: Checkpoints should exhibit visual contrast with the surrounding terrain. This contrast can result from differences in color, texture, shape, or elevation. Proximity to Intended Path: Optimal VFR checkpoints lie directly on or in close proximity to the planned flight track, enhancing navigation accuracy. Planned Altitude Consideration: When selecting checkpoints, the intended cruising altitude must be considered. Lower altitudes might obscure a chosen reference point due to elevated terrain, or it might only become visible once the aircraft has traversed over it for a limited duration. 'Isolated and prominent hills provide a good opportunity for check features.' ⇒ Correct Isolated and prominent hills stand out from their surroundings and have a considerable size. Therefore, they are appropriate ground features during VFR navigation. 'A range of hills of uniform size, with NO additional features, is the best terrain to maintain good visual checkpoints.' ⇒ Incorrect A range of hills of uniform size, with no additional features will not make any contrast with the surrounding terrain and will not help the pilot identify them during VFR navigation. 'Small rivers will be easy to spot in hilly terrain.' ⇒ Incorrect Lower altitudes might obscure a chosen reference point due to elevated terrain, or it might only become visible once the aircraft has traversed over it for a limited duration.
