key_points: Navigation by Dead Reckoning is part of the basic training for pilots
Based in the calculation of the position of airplane based in the direction and the ground distance traveled from a determined point

learning.explanation: Navigation by Dead Reckoning is part of the basic training for pilots. Based in the calculation of the position of airplane based in the direction and the ground distance traveled from a determined point. With the introduction of modern navigational techniques such as GPS and conventional radio navigational aids, this may seem outdaated technique. Reasons for why we continue to teach Dead Reckoning: 1. Creation of a Dead Reckoning encourages the pilot to consider the safest and most economical flightpath, potential threats and eventual consequences of navigational errors. 2. It is an acceptable and approved mean of navigation. Dead Reckoning can be used to navigate under Visual Flight Rules without having to rely on a radio or other navigational aids. 3. It is fail-safe mean of navigation. DR does not rely on any navigational aid, it is therefore a valuable contingency navigation method, even if the the plan is to fly with. Reference to a GPS or other navigation aid. It is likely that a route from the departure aerodrome directly to the destination will be divided into a number of route segments with the creation of turning points and waypoints. Breaking the route down into route segments brings several advantages: 1. Route segment can be selected to pass near a prominent ground feature, to help the pilot fly on track. 2. Shorter route segments minimize off-track errors by reducing the time allowed for them to develop. 3. High terrain or significant obstructions like telecommunication masts can be avoided. Really important in poor visibility conditions. Choose compact ground features as turning points and waypoints to ensure that routes are flown with precision. Large build up areas make poor turning points because of their size.

content.question: What is the greatest potential threat for VFR navigation at night?

options.A: When external lighting provides good visual cues, flying by cross-reference to instruments may cause spatial disorientation.
options.B: Exposure to red light can cause the eyes to lose dark adaptation and may cause temporary blindness.

key_points: Night flying is slightly different to daytime navigation
The pilot can see illuminated objects only, thus there is a danger of flying into terrain in the case of being lost
The so called “black-hole effect” also influences judgement, particularly distance estimation
learning.explanation: Night flying is slightly different to daytime navigation. The pilot can see illuminated objects only, thus there is a danger of flying into terrain in the case of being lost. The so called “black-hole effect” also influences judgement, particularly distance estimation. The black hole illusion occurs when flying over featureless terrain, approaching an airfield at night over water, jungle or desert. This illusion might fool the pilots into thinking they are higher than they actually are, causing them to fly dangerously low approaches - the aircraft may touch down short of the runway. "Exposure to red light can cause the eyes to lose dark adaptation and may cause temporary blindness." Incorrect. Rod cells, which allow you to see at night, incorporate a light-sensitive protein - rhodopsin. Red light breaks down rhodopsin more slowly. "It is difficult to determine the flight direction of other aircraft unless their landing lights are on." Incorrect. Navigation lights aid the determination of the flight direction of other traffic. "When external lighting provides good visual cues, flying by cross-reference to instruments may cause spatial disorientation." Incorrect. Especially at night, cross-checking the flight instruments is extremely important.

learning.explanation: The vertex of a great circle is the point where the great circle reaches the highest latitude, that is, the farthest possible distance from the equator. A great circle has two opposite vertices in the Northern and Southern Hemisphere, and these are at the same latitude. The given vortex is at latitude 50º06.4'N. Therefore, the other vertex must be at the same latitude in the opposite hemisphere: 50º06.4'S. Now, the two vertices are also 180º of longitude apart. The given vertex is at longitude 075°00.0’W. Therefore, the other vertex must be at longitude: 180°00.0’ - 075°00.0’E = 105°00.0’E.

content.question: You proceed along a great circle from point A to point B. The maximum difference between your great circle track and the corresponding rhumb line track will occur on:

key_points: The difference between the Rhumb Line track and the Great Circle track increases when the Conversion Angle increases

The Conversion Angle, determined by the formula: Conversion Angle = 1/2 x Change of Longitude x sin(Latitude) shows that for a given Change of Longitude, the Conversion Angle escalates with increasing Latitude (as sin(Latitude) increases) and reaches its maximum at high latitudes
Therefore, at high latitudes, the difference between the Great Circle track and the Rhumb Line track becomes most pronounced
